author: {'steamid': '76561198005439683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1506450966}
review:
A short and sharp game, that features endings running from moderately depressing to seriously depressing.

Pros:

Very short
Multiple endings
Some nice puzzles
An effective, simple soundtrack
Decent characterisation

Cons:

Not a looker
Very short
The endings seem somewhat random, two flags aside

Overall if it's cheap and you like point and click: get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129936651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 477, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1505390893}
review:
Richard & Alice is good Post-apocalyptic game. Now for the story.

You play as Richard a former soldier in jail for desertion, during a Post-apocalyptic snow storm. As watches tv in his cell what well someday be turned into a home for the rich, he hears something from the next cell over, when he looks he meets Alice a woman in jail murder. They get to talking and Alice tells him her story.

Okay first this game can be a little slow sometimes story wise I mean it’s not bad, just wish it had a bit more action, but it’s not too bad. This game can be depressing, but I mean that in a good way. 

And there are some bugs, like you save fill being gone but that just happened to me and I just made two fills. Okay what I liked about.

Story was good. Liked the banter between Richard & Alice. Liked the little world building. The exploring themes of hope, despair and morality. Lastly liked the dark atmosphere of the game too.

Now for stuff I did not like/could have been better.

Would have liked to meet the Polar Bear gang. Game could have had a little bit more characters to talk too. Game could have been a little longer. And lastly the save bug.

But with all that said the game was very good, and I hope someday we get a sequel or a Prequel of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993158893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1488977380}
review:
Holy crap this game is depressing.

Moar plz

author: {'steamid': '76561197970859560', 'num_games_owned': 5618, 'num_reviews': 358, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1485812438}
review: I liked the writing and the story and the characters. The game itself is mostly a series of item hunts. It is also unfortunately short (about 2 hours) for the price. Good for a dollar or two, but not 6.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041407331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1502055633}
review: I enjoyed the hell out of this game. It is excellent in terms of story and the complexity of the puzzles. I highly recommend playing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009393197', 'num_games_owned': 1835, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1502367087}
review:
The good definitely outweighs the bad. For what I paid for it (99 cents) this is an excellent game.

[u]The good[/u]

Tells a deep and poignant story
Pulls no punches
Comments well on the futility of it all
Branching storylines
Some of the puzzles are a challenge

[u]The bad[/u]

Barney can be irritating
Graphics are blah
Easy to get stuck sometimes

author: {'steamid': '76561198033452755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1501195570}
review:
Ричард и Элис это детище двух бывших успешных веб-журналистов и игровых кинокритиков. Поэтому не стоит удивляться, что главный упор здесь идет на сюжет, а остальное оказывается второстепенным. К счастью, история действительно качественная и искупает примитивную (хотя и довольно милую) графику, не очень удобный интерфейс и ужасный пиксель-хантинг (некоторые предметы действительно ОЧЕНЬ мелкие).
Помимо сюжета здесь хорошо переданная атмосфера антиутопии, когда человечество оказалось на грани выживания из-за непрекращающегося снегопада. Отличный музыкальный ряд хорошо сочетается с визуальными эффектами и передает в необходимой степени - напряжение, страх, печаль или другие негативные эмоции. Да, эта игра не про светлое будущее. По ощущениям и безысходности происходящего она близка к финалу Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, но тут есть аж 5 разных концовок с разной степенью депрессивности. Концовки зависят от выборов, которые вы будете делать по ходу игры, но, должен заметить, угадать какие именно действия имеют значение практически невозможно. Диалоги, которые, на первый взгляд, важные, не оказывают никакого влияния, а чисто символические действия могут иметь решающее значение.
Текст в игре действительно очень хороший, очень качественный, история отлично прописана и вполне достойна быть опубликованной как отдельная повесть.
Особенно мне понравился персонаж Барни. Он смелый, как лев.
Но несмотря на все это у меня есть претензия к поведению Алисы.
Читать ее НЕЛЬЗЯ никому из тех, кто игру не прошел, так как это суровый спойлер! СПОЙЛЕР!!! Если вы проходили эту игру и у вас есть мнение по моему недопониманию сюжета, пожалуйста, выскажитесь в комментариях, но обязательно используйте тег спойлера!
[spoiler] В игре Алиса говорит, что у старика, который похитил их с Барни есть лекарства. Она не хочет туда возвращаться, даже несмотря на то, что ее сыну они необходимы. Она могла бы пристрелить старика, забрать лекарства и спасти сыну жизнь. Второй вариант - она могла бы попросить помощи белых медведей. Тоже риск, но тоже есть шанс спасти сыну жизнь. Она предпочитала бегать кругами и... вы знаете, чем это закончилось. [/spoiler]

Но игру все равно стоит попробовать всем, для кого сюжет стоит на первом месте. Тем более она очень небольшая.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986156553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1402754200}
review: ¿Do you like visual novels? It plays like an rpg but is more like a VN. Kind of dark, and heartbreaking. I like it but it's too short, there are also diferent endings... [spoiler] but don't have hope. In the end your actions didn't matter that much. [/spoiler] I think is alright to give it a 6.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1499841884}
review:
Avec Richard & Alice, on touche du doigt les limites de ce que le support jeu video peut offrir. On est plus face à une histoire qu'à un jeu pointer-cliquer, c'est excessivement verbeux, très peu interactif et au final très peu ludique. 

Dans une situation climato-apocalyptique, 2 personnages au passé psychologiquement lourd se dévoilent progressivement (très progressivement) et nous amènent sur le terrain dramatique de la relativité des notions de bien et de mal en situation d'urgence ou de survie et de l'éventuel mal-être qui s'ensuit. 

Le hic est que le format du type jeux RPG-Maker blablateux et passif flingue complètement le rythme de l'histoire. A un clic tout les 5 ou 6 mots, autant s'offrir un bon recueil de nouvelles ou un petit roman d'un auteur à découvrir dont les supports numériques ou pas auront au moins le mérite de la fluidité.  Les graphismes étant du même tonneau, finallement une petite BD serait pas mal non plus. Et si votre goût du point'n'click tient à la confrontation de votre esprit hyper-logique et analytique à des énigmes bien touffues... bah, allez voir ailleurs ! Dans Richard & Alice les rares situations à résoudre par le joueur sont d'un intérêt et d'une complexité inversement proportionnels à la situation des personnages, ça oscille entre le simpliste et le néant.

Donc, bon, ces deux-là ont un petit quelque chose d'accrocheur puisque je suis allé au bout mais non, je ne peux définitivement pas recommander un jeu aussi pénible à jouer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147737340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1586645161}
review: Short but good story, recommended for those who knows they won't always live happily ever after...

author: {'steamid': '76561198023383850', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1498571855}
review:
Richard & Alice is a story and decision based point and click adventure game. It has a very immersive atmosphere clouded with mystery and an eerie sense of a dystopian world in which both Alice and Richard inhabit.

At the beginning, there is no explanation to any of the circumstances to which the world has become hostile and dangerous. The outcome of the plot revolves around decisions that you make in the game and the multiple endings are not only gut wrenching but also thought provoking. 

The world is beautifully rendered with a bleak color palette in the cold outdoor scenes and tainted with a grain filter.

My only gripes with this game are the bland puzzles, weird combinations and the lack of influence in some conversation choices.

Overall, the game has it's flaws but I would strongly recommend exploring and venturing into the dystopian world of Richard & Alice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006849221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1404338513}
review: A slow burner of a story. The elements of this game remind me of The Shining.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996912131', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1496322850}
review: I read good things about this game when I bought it quite a while ago. Finally got around to playing it and it was a complete disappointment. The writing was horrendous and the dialog attrocious - don't even get me started on the dialog of the supposed 5 year old who talked like a 3 year old. I honestly had the story figured out in the first few minutes and this should have been a warning to me. I spent the next several hours suffering through crappy puzzles and awful walking speeds, wondering when the greatness of this game would shine through the growing mountain of shit that was piling higher and higher with each mouse click.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077624382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1482808962}
review: BORING

author: {'steamid': '76561198044451069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1495121531}
review: Elements of the story were quite absorbing, but some of the text is not brilliantly written - for example, the dialogue of the five-year-old I did not find very realistic and I don't think reflected how five-year-olds actually speak! I agree with some of the previous reviewers that it takes too long for characters to walk around quite a featureless landscape, and I didn't really like the style of animation. It has the potential to be a good point and click adventure game, but it could be a lot better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098400194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 463, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1492888220}
review:
Aventura gráfica, con un argumento interesante, pero con fallos muy graves.
Es extremadamente lenta, con muy pocos escenarios en los que hay muy poca interactividad.
Los exteriores están vacíos, y con la excusa de que está todo nevado, es insufriblemente lento el recorrerlos.
La historia de Richar está desaprovechada. No tiene peso en la historia, ni apenas trasfondo.
He de decir que la relación de Alice con su hijo, y todo lo que sufre por él está muy bien llevada.
Si solventara esos fallos, la experiencia sería mucho más positiva.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055089474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1492063334}
review:
It was all right. 

Nice story, emotional and heavy. Good characters and writing. Puzzles were pretty simple but not too boring.

The main problem with the game is moving about and the visuals. This two make eachother worse, since for most of the game you must walk quite slowly through dull white areas with very little to actually look at. 

Price is fair. The game is short and simple, but enjoyable. Good if you're just looking for a little story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027282668', 'num_games_owned': 2014, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1490574229}
review: I was surprised by how much I liked this game. Not particularly for its gameplay. The gameplay is not very good; there's way too much slow walking back and forth through screens. But I really liked the story. It wasn't the most original story ever but I thought it was pretty entertaining. I would replay it to try to get the other endings but unfortunately the gameplay is so slow that I'm not sure that I really want to sit through that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075820042', 'num_games_owned': 3556, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1490571922}
review:
Point and click adventure that heavily relies on story-telling.
It's fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976832571', 'num_games_owned': 903, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1489981078}
review:
A short story-driven game set in a post-apocalyptic world in wich winter is neverending.
At times funny, sometimes sad and moving, the story really stays with you, even after you're done with it. 
There's also multiple endings, and it's a pretty easy game to 100% (legit, because f*ck SAM).
The only "con" I have is that in some dialog, the characters swear and there's just no need for that in the context.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007688772', 'num_games_owned': 1260, 'num_reviews': 648, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1488028181}
review:
Ucházející adventura situovaná v zajímavém post-apokalyptickém prostředí. Jde spíš o komorní, příběhovou záležitost se spoustou dialogů, což je trochu problém, protože primitivní herní engine s textovými okénky nedokáže příliš spolehlivě vzbuzovat emoce. Nepomáhá ani slabá grafika a animace. Není to špatné, ale za dva dny už si na to nevzpomenu.
Hra běží v předpotopním Adventure Game Enginu, má problémy s větším rozlišením a zapnutí překryvu Steamu nebo přepnutí do jiné aplikace ji úplně rozbije.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997916536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1487498404}
review:
I like point-and-click adventure games, but this one wasn't very good. It's mostly clicking through dialogue, and the dialogue is not well written. When you're not clicking through dialogue, you're wandering back and forth very slowly across the same stretch of snow, trying to figure out where you forgot to pick up an object. The art is MS Paint level, and the music and production values overall isn't any better.

The selling point is the story, which is alright. The plot has an interesting twist, but this wasn't nearly enough to make up for the game's faults--especially with the poor writing.

If you like distopian point-and-click games, try any game by WadjetEye instead: "Shardlight" is similar to this game in its subject matter, but better, and "Primordia" and "Technobabylon" are better still.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123274967', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1486641083}
review: The story is gripping and moving, and the writing for the different characters is good though there isn't a heck of a lot of personality. The game is pretty easy, with the only real challenge being the low resolution graphics. If you're looking for puzzles or humour then this isn't really the adventure game for you, but if you want to be sucked into a well written, well paced, story of mystery and despair then Richard & Alice does that job excellently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025024895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1486451658}
review:
I enjoy point and click games,  story based games with almost nothing else but story, depressing games, distopian settings, And I of course enjoy games that have multiple endings based on decisions you make/things you say (especially when morality is at the crux of those decisions). Richard & Alice is undoubtedly all of those things. But done badly...or at the very least, done in a way that is quite dissatisfactory. 

Look the core story is interesting sure. But its dragged out. ESPECIALLY by the [b] [u] HORRENDOUS [/b] [/u] walking speed. I swear that accounted for half the game. It made me stay too long in poorly done MS Paint tier environments and hate the stoic unchanging character art. 

Maybe if this game didn't have the cliche build something out of the random stuff you find point and click mechanic, had kick ass voice acting, didn't waste your time with walking so slowly, and had better pacing, maybe it'd be worth your time. But it isn't. It was an decent idea that was excuted okayishly with a non-existant budget (I surmise). 

If you want atmosphere, great art, story, decision making, exploration that isn't a contrivance/hassle, dystopia, and an air of bleakness try Primordia. This was an attempt. Nothing more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024317611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1484712821}
review:
I never understood people who hated a game and yet completed all the endings/got all the achievements. I'm now in the same club.

Richard and Alice is a depressing slog. None of the characters are interesting in the least, and the story is dull. It fails as a point and click game due to boring puzzles and the aformentioned dearth of story. Obtaining the different endings requires miniscule changes that require replaying the slow, plodding game again and again. For a game that only takes two to three hours to complete all endings, it seemed like at least twice that long. I thought that maybe the different endings would bring some insight into this game. But no. They were slight variations on a theme: you're doomed. Everyone you know is doomed. There is nothing you can do.

I can handle bleak. I can handle depressing. But I can't handle bad. This game is inexcusably dull, and I cannot in earnest recommend it to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068761861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1484274869}
review:
J'ai rarement joué à un jeu aussi laid, mal conçu et en plus avec une histoire moisie.
Je rois aussi que c'est la première fois que je laisse une critique sans un seul point positif.
Le dernier jeu steam à acheter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074304878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1483924555}
review:
I played The Charnel House Trilogy by Owlcave and I liked it a lot, so I decided to buy this one too. Quite frankly, it only lasted a couple hours, but I couldn't wait for this game to finish. To many useless dialogues. It felt they were here only to make the game last longer. Very little interactivity and things to actually click on. The graphics aren't very beautiful, but I didn't mind that much. The story was okay. Not great. Okay.

I get that this is a poorly funded project and that no miracle could be made, so this is not necessary Owlcave's fault, but instead of buying this game, buy The Charnel House Trilogy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010395257', 'num_games_owned': 3313, 'num_reviews': 469, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1450276906}
review:
Baby, it's cold outside...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vMwivn9C4M4

After an eternal winter causes a new type of apocalypse, survivors desperately try to get by, often resorting to many unsavory things.  There are some pretty cool moments here, but most are spoilerific.  Suffice to say, 2 prisoners (Richard and Alice) slowly go over what life is like on the outside and if maybe they're better off being in jail...wherever they are.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069379635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1405460883}
review: This game was absolutely amazing. It left me with an unfamiliar feeling at the end, a mixture of both discomfort and bittwersweetness at the same time. I highly recommend this for anyone looking for a cryptic gaming experience. It's been over a year and I still remember the story of Richard and Alice. It's definitely one that sticks with you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084519772', 'num_games_owned': 1576, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1483257465}
review:
For those that like hard numbers, I'd rate this game at least a 4.0/5.0, maybe even a 4.5

It's a great little indie gem of a game, and it has it all. Point and click style gaming, lots of dialogue, notes to collect, and sadder moments, including some hints as to even more terrible things, if you read between the lines.

[i]Richard & Alice[/i] takes place in the possibly near future where an ice-age apocalypse has descended on the world, causing gangs and chaos to run rampant. The game progresses via dialogue from two people who meet in nearby cells in a futuristic prison. It's not a difficult game, by any means, but the story and themes are what makes this game worth a playthrough.

The game certainly has it's darker spots, as one would expect from any post-apocalyptic narrative, and that is where the game shines. Some of those moments are in your face, some are more subtly revealed through notes and gruesome in-game discoveries. It gets you thinking about moral gray areas and what choices people make when the world goes to sh*t. I've loved other games that do this (Homefront, The Walking Dead games) because it's about seeing how people can change when the world and the rules around them change. 

It's certainly worth your time, and the game includes multiple endings to go back and try to get. I could easily see this story as a Hollywood-style apocalypse drama movie, but I don't think they could do it justice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198286740960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1590163855}
review: Wonderful little game.  Every pixel point-and-click fan should own this treasure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000900667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1480413478}
review:
A short but poignant analysis of the struggles of parenthood and coping with loss.  I found myself deeply moved by the end of this point-and-click novella.

As is typical with this style of game, there will be times when you feel stuck, and can't figure out what you're supposed to do in order to resume progression.  I would recommend against seeking a guide online, as you run the risk of spoiling what is a bloody tear-jerker of a climax.

It's short.  I played through it in under three hours.  Multiple endings though give this considerable replay value given its brevity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025816757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1489034982}
review:
Christ this is so much sadder than the synopsis makes it out to be. Like, I was expecting Death Valley levels of sadness, not the Marinaris Trench. If I'd known the, uh, twist, for lack of a better term, I probably wouldn't have played it. It's a great game, does a lot with very little, but good god in heaven the synopsis should mention Barney by name, I was not prepared, and am not dealing with it well.
If you're at all genre savvy, Barney will be obvious about two seconds after you meet him (and while he's an important part of the game there's a lot more to it, so if you're teetering on the edge of no stick with your gut) and if you think you can handle it, this is an excellent, thoughtful piece about morality and desperation, the point past where every choice is bad and you have to decide which one will hurt least, and also briefly not so much religion as faith in times of utter crisis, but if you can't please stay far away I wish somebody had been able to tell me how much worse than I expected it to be it was.
I... wasn't really satisfied with the ending I got, to be honest, and I'm not entirely sure how the cause and effect worked out, because if you'd dropped me in Alice's shoes knowing everything there was to know, somebody wouldn't have made it out of that church and it's even odd on who, to be honest, but at the same time the likelyhood of me ever having the emotional bandwidth to play through it again and find out what the other options are is slim to none.
One thing I thought worked perfectly was the walking mechanic. Wandering through a blizzard is no fun, and having movement speed be stuck at a crawl really worked for me in that sense.
I'm recommending it because it's very good at what it does but please keep your own state of being in mind, this is not for the faint of heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999793755', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1480252548}
review:
For an accidental purchase that came along within a bundle, I am SO glad I picked this up! I would have easily powered through it in one sitting if I hadn't had made prior plans to extend my social butterfly wings. 

I honestly didn't know what to expect when I installed this and I certainly didn't expect to fall in love with it the way I did. The gameplay itself is simple, as is the story and presentation of it. But don't for a second think that this devalues the impact of this game. 

Now excuse me while I try to work out how to get back home after my unexpected journey on the Feels Train.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009686082', 'num_games_owned': 1135, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1479076530}
{'steamid': '76561198070825020', 'num_games_owned': 683, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1470868037}
review: а так неплохо начиналось... Унылый квест aka визуальная новелла, история поначалу кажется многообещающей (про мужика и тетку в тюрьме, они там встретились, рассказывают свои истории, а вокруг апокалипсис), но в итоге она оказалась жуть какой дырявой. Плюс ужасно скучная квестовая часть, душные долгие диалоги. Заканчивала игру после прохождения To the moon, на контрасте это было особенно уныло. Только сюжетный поворот с мальчиком понравился

author: {'steamid': '76561198050157835', 'num_games_owned': 1409, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1476826356}
review:
Sorry, Ultimately  I ran out of interest toward the end, and was just happy to finish.  It's more "meh" than bad to me, but still I can't recommend it unless you're a point and click fan..  There are apparently multiple endings, but I had no motivation to go back and understand key turning points or what might make the story end differently.  

That said, if you like point and click adventures you might like this, as it is better than some I've played, but still, I was relieved when it was finished and just sortof felt meh about it.  (I'm generally not a big fan of point and click adventures, but this one caught my attention due to reviews and the setting, so this review might apply more to people who are more similar to myself).

+ The story is interesting, even throughtful about survival, and 
+ the puzzles generally aren't arbitrary and make sense in context.  I only had to consult walkthrough once.
+ world itself was well constructed, interesting.  
+ characters well developed, identifiable
- Lots of text/conversation to click through at various points.  This can take a while to click through, and some responses can seem a bit polite for the situation.  
- I guess I just felt like it started dragging a bit toward the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014782789', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1475872955}
review:
The game is based on a pretty interesting premise, the world has been plunged into eternal snowfall and you're locked up in prison with only the company of another prisoner in the cell across the hall. The two of you begin talking and as the player you take turns controlling Alice in her flashbacks, and Richard in the present time.

After completing the game and going through every ending, my opinion is that this is worth playing; however, if you are a completionist and want to eventually get every ending, you should play using a guide from the very beginning.  The movement in the game is very slow and if you don't make save files at the right times, you will spend several hours re-doing content to get the different endings and it's pretty frustrating.

Playing through this game once is enjoyable, but trying to see the different endings can be very time-consuming if you aren't smart with your saves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000802368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 191, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1476631986}
review:
Сразу оговорка - игра на AGS (а это обычно выглядит даже хуже, чем RPG Maker). Причем явно не самый красивый представитель AGS-квестов. И анимация и сама графика, мягко говоря, так себе. 
Геймплей на 75% состоит из прокликивания диалогов. Иногда игроку наконец дают управление и можно немного побродить, выполнить несложную квестовую задачку.
Но в отличие от всяких красивых больших Telltale игр, здесь присутствует хорошо поданный сюжет и качественные диалоги. Так что прочитал игру с удовольствием.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983062775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1475290885}
review:
Welcome to my review of Richard & Alice!

In A Nutshell: 

Pros: 

-Strong, interesting storyline from two perspectives.
-Great Apocalyptic Theme!
-Macabre undertones and adult language.
-Multiple Endings (Though some debate over how to trigger each!)
-Fairly Cut-&-Dry steps and puzzle solutions.
-Steam Achievements and Trading Cards! 

Cons: 

-A bit too much back-and-forth travel towards the end.
-Some puzzles have fairly obscure solutions.
-No way to Stop an action after clicking (such as going through a door by mistake).
-Basic sounds and effects, and dated graphics (though Retro-licious!)

Full Review: 
 
 As a fan of Point-&-Click style games, not to mention a post-apocalypse theme, I was really excited to get my hands on Richard & Alice. I found the story to be intriguing, with just enough darkness and sadness to be appropriate for the setting, and some “adult language” thrown in for good measure. While it felt like most of the plot revolved around Alice’s half of the backstory, and the fate of her child, the developers definitely tied in both Richard and Alice’s history nicely in the end. I love that there’s multiple endings, though there’s some pretty heated debates over how to trigger them -- fortunately, there’s a few Steam Guides available if you need some help. I had the “Parting Ways” for my play-through, which I found to be appropriate and fairly satisfying, though it did feel like more of a cliffhanger than most of the other ending possibilities. 

 All in all, Richard & Alice is a worthy addition to any Point-&-Click library, especially if you like the added bonuses of Steam Achievements and trading cards! The story is a little gloomy at times, and the puzzles – and tedious walking back and forth towards the end – slowed down the momentum at times, but in the end it definitely receives my recommendation.

In Conclusion: 7/10 

[i]This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198037506865', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1041, 'last_played': 1474741028}
review:
I couldn't do it, i really liiked the story, I quite liked the style, but I gave up on (i think) day 6 for one reason.  THE WALKING.  It's so blinking slow and there's absolutely no reason for it.  When it takes more than 2 minutes to walk between two buildings on two screens it's ridiculous.

Also there is no indication atall where you canleave one area and go to another.

Possibly a good game, but killed by some stupid design decsions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136643294', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1473456509}
review: Отличная игра. Грустный взрослый (и по диалогам, и по ставящимся игрой вопросам)... пост-апокалипсис? Проходить на несколько концовок можно, конечно, но передвижение героев ну о-о-очень медленное, что может отбить желание. Но они стоят того, чтобы перепройти игру! Есть гайды. Русификатор недавно хороший появился. Превалирование диалогов над геймплеем нельзя записывать в минусы. Графика "обычная" пиксельная. Может пробить на слезу (было несколько моментов, когда "подступало"). Брал по скидке, но и фулл-прайс (150р. всего) свой она однозначно стоит!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010709004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1473524863}
review: En una ag la historia lo es todo. Y ésta me está enganchando.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972649989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1472485264}
review:
Отличный сюжет скрывается за примитивной графикой. Рассказывается интересная история о двух людях, переживших морозный конец света. Единственная претензия к сюжету - совершенно непредсказуемые концовки. Чего бы вы ни делали, как бы ни обдумывали свои решения, вы не сможете угадать, чем все кончится.
Одно из достоинств игры - она короткая, поэтому не успевает надоесть. С другой стороны, за счет этой краткости и отсутствия озвучки персонажей не успеваешь к ним привыкнуть, начать сочувствовать.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189376502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1472228060}
review:
Dark, dreary and macabre: all things I usually enjoy in modern games. So why didn't I like Richard & Alice? A few reasons. The gameplay isn't very fun, and as a point-and-clicker, there are far better examples. The storyline here, pitch black as it is, falls apart into a self-righteous, quasi-religious, philosophical mess, where any potential poignancy and relevance becomes impossible to take seriously due to comical 'Dragon Warrior'-styled graphics. There's simply far too little stuffing here for one to take the game seriously, so Richard & Alice ends up just being dark for darkness' sake, without the character development or back story required to really make anyone care about what's happening to the folks as the story unfolds. 

If you're looking for a good point and click horror game, I'd recommend the Black Mirror trilogy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249237304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1471398466}
review:
A pretty decent point & click game. It took me around ~4 hours to beat and the rest is used for achievements. The story speaks of of loneliness, desperation, and a world that has to fight against two inexorable enemies: nature and human kind. If you look at the gameplay, there's not such a great challenge, but, on the other hand, you may find dramatic and somewhat decent storytelling. There are 5 possible endings in the game, and with replays from several save points throughout the game, I was only able to arrive at 2 of them. Each offers a slightly different potential outcome for our two main characters.

My main complain with this game is the huge frame drops, and it always happens whenever Alice (2nd screenshot) goes outside. I tried several things with no avail, so I just sucked it up and finished the game. There's also the problem where I found it a a bit hard to become emotionally invested in the characters. After all, if everyone is a survivalist animal, why should you care which animal survives and which one doesn’t? The game tries a little too hard to tug on your heart strings with Alice’s cute and naive five year old son, Barney, and while Richard does at least invite a little bit of sympathy, the same can’t be said with Alice. In describing her childhood and her background, she strikes me as a perpetually depressed melancholic for whom the Snowpocalypse is just another average day. She is the kind of person who would be insufferable even in a utopia. Other than that, it also feels like the game didn't really live up to its own potential, and instead of leaving you with a rewarding experience, it constantly hammered you with a message that all humans eventually succumb to their evil nature, and that none of us are deserving of good fortune, nor will we find it, in the event of global tragedy—and that, frankly, perseverance will be a wholly useless endeavor should we ever reach such a level of desperation.

Maybe that's all true, and maybe Richard & Alice at least deserves credit for being able to stimulate this kind of discussion. It may also deserves some credit for being engaging enough for me to want to play it to its conclusion, even though that conclusion isn’t very satisfying. It isn’t a terrible game by a long stretch, and it is possible to like it if you don’t mind playing through what amounts to an interactive novel. My final rating: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198051841253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1471267497}
review: Wow, what a great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035829376', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1470435994}
review: If you are a fan of end time stories and like "The Road" or "The walking dead", this is for you. There are some point & click adventure puzzles but they are not very hard and are mainly there to progress the story with some action from the player. If you are in the mood for this setting and have three hours to spare, go for it, you won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131888399', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1469558094}
review:
I want to like this game, but it is poorly optimised. It defaults to a small window, to get the game fullscreen you have to manually edit the acsetup.cfg file in the file directory. When set to fullscreen, it opens the window still as small but you now have blackscreen, so it's less distracting.
When looking past this, the game itself is a great point-and-click game. Although the graphics are lacking, the story is well written and so is the dialogue. The movement can be painstakingly slow, especially when being stuck, solving a puzzle.
I would only recommend this game to hardcore point-and-click enthusiasts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031651888', 'num_games_owned': 798, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1468014340}
review: Une gentille petite histoire dramatique, mais sans réelle interactivité. Les énigme n'en sont pas vraiment, juste quelques objets à ramasser utiliser, mais le scénario est intéressant. Cela divertit quelques heures.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006529776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1467686171}
review:
Dialog is everything in Richard & Alice.
The writing is masterful.
Richard  & Alice is a subtle psychological and philosophical
view of human beings trying to survive  an environmental apocalypse.
Some jaded game players will not have the patience
or understanding to appreciate minimalism.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966676194', 'num_games_owned': 1621, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1467768189}
review:
Whelp, im pretty confident I have spent as much time trying to get this game to work as I would have playing it.  I can't recommend a game that has rendered itself completely impossible for me to even load.  It's not like it's my first rodeo working with finicky games or stuff made in weird / old / poorly optimized engines: I've messed with rpg maker runtimes and tweaked graphical settings for bad game launches (dead island and dark souls launches comes to mind), I've disabled dual monitor support for games that refused to load on the appropriate monitor, but I've never had a game just simple refuse to budge.  No combination of settings in the set up will get this to run on my computer (i5 2500K 8gb ram, r9 280x on windows 10), I just keep getting a never ending message about my graphics drivers not being suitable.  Putting it in different compatibility modes doesnt seem to help either.  I can't really find anything online discussing my issue specifically either that has provided any major insight to getting this game to work.

I won't blame the developers specifically, because this seems a product of the engine they used to make this game called Adventure Game Studio.

Anywho, I was attracted to this game because of the story so I suppose I will just watch a let's play since I cannot for the life of me get this game to load.

No disrespect to the publisher or developer, the money isnt even the issue as I bought it in a pack with the fantastic Charnal House Trilogy, just disappointed I am not able to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198264297048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1467642392}
review: A basic point-and-click game, but with a very interesting narrative. It wasn't my favorite, but it was still good overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966594088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1467579950}
review:
This is a basic point & click adventure game - the kind of game that I've played dozens of throughout my life. Its setting is post apocalyptic, and there's nothing really special about it. In fact, the characters don't have any other animations than walking around. Whenever they do anything else than that, the camera cuts out. The setup screen for the game acts as if DirectX and antialiasing will be used, but I could probably draw this game in MS Paint - lol.

I bought this game as part of a bundle that was on sale, and you might say that I suffered through it just to get it out of the way, with the occational sigh and groan from boredom. I exclaimed "Finally!" when it was over.

Let's hope that the horror trilogy that this game was bundled with, is better.
...because if it's any more like this game, then I probably won't make it through a whole trilogy of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007270309', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1467421472}
review: An amazing game that contains a story so heartfelt it will leave you questioning human nature. The gameplay flows smoothly, and the text is incredibly personalized for each character. It is clear that the developer(s) put a lot of time and love into the game, and thanks to that this game has been an incredible experience. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047534340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1467270405}
review:
Took me a while to play the game again and then finish it :)
but it was a fairly nice story.

Quite predictive how parts of the ending will go

The moving mechanics were annoying a bit, I'd prefer the keyboard not the mouse.

But overall nice game

author: {'steamid': '76561198105058606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1425724297}
review:
I've played Richard & Alice many months ago, but I still remember the story and characters very clearly. In fact, they're the strongest points of this game. It's set in a pretty brutal, post-apocalytpic world (more like The Road rather than Mad Max). Some puzzles can be solved in multiple ways, and you'll be making decisions along the way that influence the ending of the game (there are a couple of them, and they're quite different). 
My biggest gripe with this game is the character movement speed. You'll be making your way across the map at snail's pace, and given that backtracking and exploring your surroundings is often required, it can become really frustrating. However, if you like dark, intriguing stories, and deep, flawed characters, give this game a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068033913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1466087687}
review:
Данная игра повествует историю Алисы и Ричарда, которые сидят в тюрьме для беженцев после апокалипсиса. Сюжет данный игры рассказывает о похождениях Алисы до её попадания в данное место, что никак не радует. Эта женщина настолько тупая и неспособная, что мне просто хотелось её смерти. Про Ричарда же разговор короткий, 7-8 строк в конце игры. Игра слишком нудная и однообразная.
Оценка: 2/10 - внимание, такая же скорость была у всех персонажей игры.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080704090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1465872310}
review:
Eurgh.

I really like adventure games. I really like adventure game studio. I really like Owl Cave. I was even really intrigued by the premise of this story. I really wish I liked Richard and Alice.

But it's soooo sloooow. Not pacing-wise. But the movement speed of the characters is so slow, the dialogue progression is so slow, and the thought of replaying this game to see the different endings made me want to tear my eyeballs out.

The other problem is the kid in the story, Barney. Especially early on, in Alice's first story, he makes the story into The Room.  They're locked in a tiny room by an angry man who comes in and (possibly rapes alice and) have to work together to escape their long imprisonment. It is The Room but with different names, and I hated that story too. 

Maybe it's just my virulent hatred of children, but I found Barney to be generally irritating. I know kids in stories like these are usually there to make the unpleasantness of the surroundings all the starker, and it probably would have been a very dull game without someone for Alice to talk to, but in later chapters where you go out on your own ocassionally it wasn't so bad. I guess I should be grateful Barney doesn't have some kind of transliterated speech impediment. Sigh.

Honestly, I'd probably be easier on the game if it was free, but I bought this puppy. I paid for this and got The Charnel House for free. Nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043108500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 767, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1460769598}
review: The story is good, and so does the puzzle. Though I dont know if its just me encountering this, but at the snow level the characters move VERY slow. Which took long to reach your destination. Not sure whether something wrong with my pc or the game, or thats just how it goes in the story (like maybe they walk through deep snow). But other than that, its a good game and remember that this game is a puzzle game. Give this a try if you like stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968170388', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1402961152}
review:
Brilliant adventure gane that is light on puzzles and heavy on story.  The story is interesting, mature and gripping while not being gruesome or cliche in a way that I have never encoutered in a game before.  

Also, the gameplay supports the plot rather than being an unnecesary distraction as in often purely plot focused games.

The graphics are what they are, but you are not going to be playing the game for the graphics.

Must play.  Two thumbs up.

Oh, and it's short.  I finished it in 3 hours.  That's a good thing, it means there is no unnecessary fluff added to waste your time.  I wish there was a genre for story based games that one can finish in one sitting, like one can watch a movie.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107393638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1462940691}
review:
I doubt I'll say anything new here, but this game was seriously *affecting* so I had to say something, so here's a brief summary of what I liked. If you appreciate atmospheric, plot-driven games and don't mind walking around a little too slowly then this is well worth the asking price.

GAMEPLAY

You won't struggle with many puzzles - most of Richard's involve only what is at hand in his cell - but they do require enough lateral thinking to avoid boredom and don't succumb to that old point-and-click illogic (put the rubber duck on the stick because that's what you have and voilá!).

STORY

The post-apocalptic setting is understated and believable. It makes the already well-written interactions all the more heart-wrenching. This is not a long game - took me a 3-hour run with one instance of wandering around for the last big puzzle (I forgot to check a cabinet). But the journey is instantly engrossing and uses minimalist audio and visuals to its advantage, creating a melancholic and foreboding sense throughout. The beauty in this game is implicit - it tackles some seriously dark themes without being gratuitous and asks philosophical questions without being pretentious.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978409104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1406408253}
review: I picked this up as it promised to provide a decent story with some decent gameplay. Unfortunately nothing could be further from the truth. The story was predictable at best and the gameplay takes maybe the better part of an afternoon. I'm sure there are some people who will like it, but for someone who is used to games that can last 200+ hours with masterful storytelling and compelling gameplay, this title does a great deal more than fall short. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077719495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1460243438}
review: This shorter post-apocalyptical game is brimming with joy and laughter- oops I meant to say grim themes and human savagery that accompany any game set in a post-apocalyptical context. The game is not incredibly difficult to play nor is the plot hard to understand however there are a few elements that are left up to the player to interoperate for themselves. I really enjoyed this game and going back to see all the alternative endings and their grimness. This game gave me 6.5 hours of play including replaying the game to earn all achievements and a few times I left the game running and got distracted by something else in my home.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961734538', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 336, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1460235576}
review:
Ahh this is frustratingly close. You can see the love that's been poured into it, and it feels mean-spirited to give it a thumbs down when it is exactly the genre i most enjoy, but it just doesn't quite work.

Richard & Alice is an indie adventure game, primarily narrative driven and with minimal puzzles. It might have worked better without the puzzles, since they are all fairly contrived, but that's not a big deal. The dialog between the two title characters in cells opposite from one another is quite good and those emotional beats are the highlight of the game. Unfortunately the flashbacks ruin the whole setup. These focus on an extremely annoying child and his mother's cringe-inducing babytalk and insipid doting. About 5 minutes in you will want them both to die painfully, but instead of the story progressing past that stage you have to sit through a whole nother hour of it. Eventually the game rushes to tie everything up in a 2 minute finale that doesn't have any emotional weight because the motivations revealed in the flashbacks were so shallow. It's a real shame, because the basic concept has a lot of promise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040828725', 'num_games_owned': 901, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1459625241}
review:
The story here is worth the time playing. It's a fairly short game, and inexpensive. It is not, by any means, perfect. In fact, there were a lot of drawbacks. But as a mystery/adventure P&C, it's enjoyable.

PROS:
- Good story, even if the ending was expected
- Suspenseful, great use of dialogue timing and pace.
- The characters were believable, and you actually care about them.

CONS: 
- There were some confusing moments thanks to seemingly unimportant events having a huge impact at the end. I took about a week break playing, so that added to the confusion.
- Some objects are so incredibly tiny that your mouse may have trouble finding and clicking.
- So much walking. I wish there was a fast track button so you don't spend half the time going back to buildings.
- The blizzard sound (wind) was grating. 
- Some dialogue was repetitive. 
- Newspapers/diaries were hard to read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067569086', 'num_games_owned': 170, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1458403064}
review:
First of all, if you dont like click and point games then theres no point in playing this one. I found this one very pleasant, its my first indie click and pointer game though so there might be revolutionary better games in the same category out there but this one made it for me and Im planning on playing more similar games in the future.

The plot was nice and short enough to keep you hooked. It was a very easy game and I could easily play through it without guides even though Im a superbeginner. 
The art wasnt fantastic but hey, its a clicker game! The characters moved sooooo slow though, Id love for them to move a bit faster especially considering the time youll spend looking for things in just big white spaes of snow. 

Overall good game if youre open for something new.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117280501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1447300655}
review:
Depressing...

6 of 5 must play.
5 of 5 great story great game-play.
4 of 5 great story average game-play.
3 of 5 average story great game-play.
2 of 5 play only if it's your favourite genre.
1 of 5 play if you have nothing better to do.
0 of 5 play if you're a masochist.
-1 of 5 avoid.

Richard & Alice score is 2 of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051658653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1457375618}
review: Overlooked gem. Incredible post-apocalyptic atmosphere with a deep story. I'd also say this is a horror, atleast for me it was. Not because of usual banal monsters, no. But because of amazing suspence and atmosphere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995314923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1457031778}
review: A well written story about the dovetailing lives of two people struggling to live in a post-apocalyptic world. Deals with the decay of human morality in difficult circumstances, and is guaranteed to make you think. Puzzles are pretty reasonable and thankfully don't get too far into adventure game logic. The graphics can be a little inconsistent in quality, but when they're good they look fantastic. Music is also fitting and impressive, I'd love if the soundtrack was available on Steam! Well worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198181722381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1457065824}
review:
The irony of eating ice cream while playing Richard & Alice was strong.

Richard & Alice was one of the most compelling games I've played story-wise. The pairing of the desperate storyline and the weather calamity surrounding the characters is extremely effective, and often left me with a pang of dread in my stomach. 

A great game if you want story without the stress of combat/dying. However, it is still packed full of drama.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008480668', 'num_games_owned': 1482, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1480988663}
review:
Richard and Alice isn’t about the graphics. It is a story based game that has a focus on the narrative. That being said the simple style of the game talks to the simplicity of Owl Cave’s vision. It’s slightly bland in some cases but never looks bad and I think that it is a fitting look and feel for the game as a whole. There isn’t a great deal of audio in the game but hearing eerie music and raging winds did convey a sense of unease and foreboding that added a much needed layer to the game, something above reading endless reels of text while waiting for the chance to solve the puzzles.

Richard and Alice has multiple endings so it is worth playing through a couple of times however once you know where to use item A all of the challenge has gone from the game. If you are a fan of point and click adventures then it would be value for money, unfortunately with no real replayability past the couple of endings and there’s not much else to expect from this game for anyone other than hardcore point and click fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164151349', 'num_games_owned': 2681, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1456690343}
review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Intriguing story set in a post-apocalyptic world that centres around a man named Richard and his prisoner counterpart, Alice. You take turns playing as either Richard or Alice, though Alice's part is far greater, and her story is told entirely through flashbacks (i.e. events that have already transpired).

[h1]What I liked[/h1]
[olist]
    [*][u]Good story[/u] - Far too predictable for my liking, but still interesting. The use of flashbacks as a way of unfolding the tale was fascinating; I always felt like I wanted to find out more and that kept me playing.
    [*][u]Has a proper ending[/u] - I hate games where they leave you hanging and don't resolve things adequately if at all. Thankfully, [i]Richard & Alice[/i] is [b]not[/b] one of those games.
    [*][u]Interesting setup[/u] - You experience playing as someone in a jail cell, and another outside roaming in the open world. Nice contrast.
    [*][u]Exciting[/u] - Has its fair share of drama and even gore, though the gore part could've been amped up 1000 times more yet. (Pixel blood isn't all that shocking, especially in minute quantities.)
    [*][u]Graphics are ok[/u] - AGS-type scenery here, but it worked. (Except for the character artwork which I didn't like. See point #5 under [i]"What I didn't[/i]" below.)
    [*][u]Has a bit of replay value[/u] - If you missed out on achievements. [i]See point below.[/i]
    [*][u]Many achievements[/u] - A handy way of seeing if you missed out on any story elements. Upon first completing the game I realised I'd missed out on several; will replay to get them.
[/olist]

[h1]What I didn't[/h1]
[olist]
    [*][u]Too short[/u] - Approximately 2+ hours max for me. Most of it was spent clicking through looooong conversations, or reading picked up notes and stuff.
    [*][u]No challenge at all[/u] - Partly because of the limited screens available to you (see point below), the answers as to what to do next were way too obvious, especially since there were so few inventory items too.
    [*][u]Limited exploration[/u] - At any point of time, only 1-3 screens are accessible. Most of the time it's just 1.
    [*][u]Some puzzles didn't make sense[/u] - In one instance, you [i]must[/i] find a tray and use it, even though you quite clearly have a notebook [i]and[/i] newspaper which could be used for the [i]exact same purpose[/i]. [b]Thumbs down for [i]non-creative[/i] puzzle-solving![/b]
    [*][u]Characters are cutesy-looking sprites[/u] - Didn't work for me. We have a really [i]serious story[/i] which tackles many [i]heavy issues[/i] here, so I'd have appreciated more "adult-looking" characters and not some manga-ish kawaii dwarf people. It really undermined the whole affair. There is the right game for anime-style peeps, and this ain't one of 'em.
    [*][u]No voice[/u] - Being nitpicky here, but if you consider the game was like 80% conversation, this would've greatly added to the atmosphere.
    [*][u]Barebones sound & music[/u] - No music in many scenes; just background sound. Many a time it was silence, or felt akin to it. Seemed kinda empty.
[/olist]

[h1]Summary[/h1]
I grabbed this during sale at S$1.62 (~US$1.15). Probably wouldn't pay more than what I did for it, due to the short length and limited adventure game puzzling. But the story was a breath of fresh air and I don't regret the experience at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140442560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1456292579}
review:
If you can get this game on the cheap, it's worth it. It's far, far from perfect, but it's well written enough to be worth a purchase.

The world has frozen over into an apocalyptic hellscape and it never stops snowing. The government struggles to maintain relevance, people starve to death on the daily, and there is very little to hope for. Richard and Alice, the titular characters, find themselves in a prison that is actually a test facility for people to shelter themselves away from the weather in. The two quickly hit it off, and with alternating stories, we learn about what happened to Alice that landed her in there and how the two plan on escaping. To say much more would be to ruin the surprises the game holds, but it;s a mostly well done story, even though there are som confusing elements by the end (that might be cleared up by seeing the other endings).

The issues lie in the puzzles and graphics. Puzzles are nothing more than key hunts, and trying everything you have on everything in the environment. They grow tedious when in the big areas later on, in aprt because of the deathly slow walking speed (with no option to speed up). The graphics, while technically not horrendous stylistically, are not fitting for the grim tone this game portrays. It references such bleak post apocalyptic fiction such as The Road, but the visuals in the game are not conducive to the similar atmosphere its going for.

Still, it goes on sale regularly, and like I said, is pretty well written and intriguing. As long as you can handle some tedium, it's worth the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007368722', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1455568657}
review:
This is one of those games that makes me wish there was a neutral rating option on Steam -- a sort of "indifferent shrug" between the thumbs up and thumbs down.  I got the game practically for free thanks to a Steam coupon -- without it I would probably never have realized that it existed.  It was a way to spend a few hours.  I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy it but I also don't care about it enough to try for the alternate endings.

In a genre awash with truly abominable games going back decades, many from large, reputable developers, Richard and Alice does not deserve to be lumped in with the awful majority.  It is not a bad game.  But neither is it particularly inspired.  I don't feel strongly enough about the game to give it a thumbs down, but be warned that you'll probably only /like/ this game if you are a big fan of adventure games and also bleak drama.

I can't even call the game post-apocalyptic, because while the game is clearly post-apocalyptic the apocalypse in this case is the most banal thing imaginable.  No zombies or battle cars here.  Not even a radioactive or biohazardous wasteland.  And that kind of sums up the story, here -- it's got the set-up to be something, but it's just not compelling.  The characters aren't unlikable, they're just bland.  The story isn't boring, it's just hollow.

The puzzles never really had me scratching my head, although I did have to cheat once because there is an item the game tells you is present but hidden from view in one chapter and you have to remember and go back for it in a later chapter.  I did not.  

Why they don't just give you the item immediately is unclear to me, but there is a running theme of a lack of consideration toward the player in the game.  At one point you need to reach something in the middle of a lake.  You can't reach it from this side of the lake, though -- the game makes you walk all the way around to the other side, where the gap is slightly narrower.

Incompetech.com did the music in the game.  I like Macleod's work.  I also like his graph paper.

The graphics are simple but they serve their purpose.  The weird thing about the graphics is how many graphical settings the game has.  Up to 8x anti-aliasing!  2560x1600 resolution!  One of the settings is labeled "powerful CPUs only."  I'm not sure what that means, because this game doesn't look like it should strain an abacus.  

I'm not criticizing -- I'm not a big believer in HD/4K/ultra-high nonsense, and you can see what the graphics look like in the screenshots above.  If it's going to turn you off, don't buy the game.  But honestly, they're not so bad that they're a point against.

In short, Richard and Alice is serviceable.  I won't be so cruel as to call it forgettable, but it is certainly not memorable.  If you like adventure games and stories about the worst parts of parenthood, the dark side of humanity, and snow, it might just be worth your six bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114096304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1451255315}
review: Loved this game. Emotional, enveloping, and discreetly philosophical, with well-reasoned characters and simple but effective design. There are multiple endings but it wasn't very clear what I could have done differently to achieve any of them, and I thought there was too much lengthy dialogue to be worth a replay (I'm a story-driven person and didn't notice if there was a skip dialogue option or not). Regardless, the only ending I got left me reeling, and I've read forums documenting the other endings and would have been satisfied, if a little mystified (which I like in a game), with all of them. Firm recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964863427', 'num_games_owned': 1547, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1454775207}
review: Sorry to say that, but this one did nothing for me. I played it till the end, but it seemed to sort of fall flat on its nose in the end. It tried to build some tension and develop the relation of the main protagonists, and unravel several layers of secrets, but in the end, it sort of did not work. For me. It may work for you, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025627521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1453358963}
review:
This game is all about its story. The point and click setup is faithful, but the game is very slow, and you'll spend most of your time in this game reading and moving at a snail's pace. Despite this, I still wholeheatedly reccomend Richard & Alice. The storytelling is fantastic, and the puzzles are unique and creative. It feels very rewarding and personal to solve puzzles and figure things out. The game asks you to get crafty with minimal options, and provides nicer breakups from your standard "fetchquest" fare. It made me feel smart to play a point-and-click game. At its worst, the limited options it gives you makes for the "click on everything until it works" method alot easier. In most situations what I had to do made sense, except for one of the prison puzzles.

Besides that, the only other gameeplay criticism I have to make is that the game could've been more interactive. We've seen faster paced RPG-maker-esque games with action segments like The Witch's House, so I was really expecting to play through a chase scene or a stealth puzzle instead of having it happen off-screen. Regardless, the game does what it can, and it does it well. (Aside from the bad endings of course)

Every character serves a purpose. Alice faces a single parents' struggle alongside trying to stay hopeful and survive. The gang members put their own survival above all else and it tells you about what kind of people they were before the apocalypse. Richard and Alice talk alot about what in humanity is worth saving, and how much that takes precedent over their own survival. It's all so well-planned. I feel like the writing is nothing too revolutionary, but it's never been executed so well in a non-VN video game.

The ending segments to Richard & Alice are something different. Instead of the game falling flat on its face with a super tragic ending to the characters we personally relate to in order to shock us and showcase "the concequences of poor moral behavior", this game gives you some morals to think about and uphold. Quotable statements about humanity. Philosophical meaning behind character actions. It's just...a really good game with a story, okay? Go check it out at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029560158', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1453063428}
review:
Interactive point and click story driven game. i felt the plot was deep enough to keep me playing from start to finish. while i did have my suspoissions on what was would happen next, it unraveled in a way that was more then intresting enough to keep me hooked.
Give it a go if you got a ~3hrs,

author: {'steamid': '76561198056424700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1452805875}
review:
This is [i]not[/i] a game, but, instead Richard & Alice is a very good graphic and [i]short[/i] novel. Really, really [i]short[/i].

As far as you read, understand and think about the story, it is really able to give you strong feelings. Sometimes the talkings are a bit too much pedants, but fortunately they are just few moments.

If you care about the story, it makes you wonder. Otherwise, if you are looking something else, simply do not buy.

Graphic [i]short[/i] novel: 8/10
Game: 1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198094618840', 'num_games_owned': 366, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3976, 'last_played': 1452577103}
