author: {'steamid': '76561198020209821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1451776039}
review:
Un'avventura interessante, questa Richard & Alice. Non tanto come difficoltà, poichè risulta essere un gioco piuttosto semplice e di breve durata, ma come trama e intreccio narrativo, interessante ed emozionante.
Dal punto di vista tecnico non è sicuramente brillante, purtroppo, ma fortunatamente la trama riesce a compensare qualsiasi lacuna grafica.
Chi ha voglia di provare un gioco rilassante, poichè non complesso, ma che trascina il giocatore nella voglia di scoprire cosa stia succedendo, sicuramente non rimarrà deluso da questo titolo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020864073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1451686473}
review: Really good, thought-provoking story with some philosophical depth & immersive atmosphere combined with simple gameplay. Strongly recommend...

author: {'steamid': '76561198001155356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1451458733}
review: This game was part of a group of indie games I have been waiting eagerly to play. After being thoroughly disappointed with "Gone Home", "A Story about My Uncle", and "Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons" (though less so with this one), I finally found the game I was looking for. "Richard and Alice" is the 'Rated-R', apocalyptic sibling of "To the Moon". It features excellent mood, solid writing, engaging plot, and tons of mystery. Since it received worse ratings then the previously listed disappointments one might be tempted to think it worse. However, in my opinion, it’s far better. The point and click type mechanic may turn some off and it’s likely that gamers from an older generation will appreciate it far more than younger ones. It takes a bit of imagination to enjoy, the better you are at that the more enjoyable it is. This game really is the gem in the rough that so many other games, claiming the title, actually fail to be. Ratings aren’t everything; I almost missed out on this game because of my disappointment with much higher rated ones. I absolutely recommend this experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996550048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1451266857}
review:
richard & alice is a game mostly about alice telling richard, whilst they're both imprisoned in an underground jail, about her days surviving a snowy apocalypse with her young son. the nice thing i can say about the game is that it is well-written; the dialogue is believable and the themes the story discusses are handed competently, if not exactly profoundly.

everything else about the game is kind of terrible though. the worst part is the walking speed, which is ludicrously slow. the environments are very small, but it can still take a minute or two just to get from one end of a map to another; this becomes very tedious when backtracking gets involved, usually to fetch an item to solve one of the game's puzzles, if they could even be called that considering how mundane and obvious their solutions are. the only time i got stuck was when i couldn't figure out that a path to another area opened up, and that's only because it wasn't pointed out textually nor visually. multiple endings are usually a plus, but considering that their flags aren't always at the end of the game the busywork required to get them makes them far less appealing.

the game is not very pretty either, with minimal animation and bland maps (despite there being only like, 15 or so), and the music is either royalty-free or otherwise unmemorable. i've also experienced an issue where the audio stutters every time the scene changes; i realize that adventure game studio isn't the best engine, but i've played games made in it that are far more graphically intensive yet felt like they ran better. lastly, there's a cameo that's so hamfisted it honestly feels like advertising for a much better game.

overall, richard & alice kept me interested enough to see what would happen next, but that's it. the glacial pace of its gameplay was annoying, i don't feel like i've experienced anything new from its story, and while the characters and events were realistic, perhaps even sympathetic, i can't say i truly cared about any of them. i've gotten 3 out of 5 endings, including the one that involved the most effort, but none of them were particularly remarkable and i really don't feel like putting in another half-hour of walking back and forth just to get the last two.

i'd like to say i'll end up forgetting this game existed, but i'll probably remember it if only because of how intensely banal it ended up being. so that's something i guess. this is the end of the review. the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044622757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1451255896}
review:
Such a little gem of a game.

If you're into text-heavy adventure games, give this a go. The story is well written and keeps you engaged throughout.

It may not have the amount of puzzles you're used to from other, older adventure games, but with this strong a story it's like reading a good book.

I certainly got my money's worth and then some.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042853096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1451081847}
review: I applaud the artistry that this game has - I think it is a cool concept: however the game is basically a point-and-click visual novel. I find this game difficult to play through and I can't really recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157386667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1419901913}
review: I played this game all the way through a long time ago but I remember being thoroughly disappointed and wishing I could get that two hours of my life back. Very little actual game play, annoying controls, and long fully text-based story that really wasn't all that touching or interesting. Would not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159032539', 'num_games_owned': 2624, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1448983776}
review:
What i like about the game:

- set in a post apocalyptic world where the endless snow has covered the earth.
- dark story (no cheerfull moment in the game, it all sad and quite depressing story).
- at some point in alice story there is a really heartbreaking moment and that really shock me. [spoiler] oh god, why she did that?[/spoiler]
- multiple ending.

What i dislike:

- resolution stuck at 640x400
- can't go fullscreen
- not detailed graphic, so sometime i miss some item.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992906798', 'num_games_owned': 13408, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1448587376}
review: Nice lil' time waster that won't take more than 3 hours to complete a single run through. It does have 5 separate endings depending on your choices within the game, so it has some replay value if you are looking to get the most out of it. Nice story and solid art design, with puzzles that are simple but effective. Well worth the asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006330850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1448148152}
review: Sólo un poco de historia dramática, unas pocas (sobre 12) pantallas, controles y gráficos muy primitivos y juego muy corto. No comprar salvo que sea de rebajas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012962211', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1447763480}
review:
This is BLEAK. From top to bottom, start to finish, it's bleak. And the "revelations" are all clearly telegraphed from the start because we've all pretty much seen this story before. The endings, all of them, are nihilistic and the only voice of non-nihilism is clearly written by someone who has no idea how a religious person should sound. Also, the puzzles are pretty minimal (one or two per chapter) and pretty simple, mainly there to give you a sense of agency (and unlock the different endings) in between loooooooooooooooong dialogue exchanges. But is it worth playing? Yeah. I'd say it is. I enjoyed that they made Richard the one playable in the "present" and Alice the one playable in the "past." Also, the environmentalism is subtle and almost never rises to the "OMG-GUYS-GLOBAL-WARMING-IS-TOTES-REAL-AND-THE-MOST-IMMEDIATE-AND-HORRIBLE-THREAT-EVARRRRR!!!!" level of other games/movies/books, so it's worth playing just for that. 

Basically, buy this and play it if you feel like playing a simple, bleak visual novel about a world of perpetual winter and the inevitable decay of human society. 
Do NOT buy it or play it if you are looking for an actual game. 'Coz a game it ain't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150278571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1446706839}
review: Simple graphics, but such a poignant, heartbreaking story... I got a sad conclusion to what i wholeheartedly believe is a gentle and brave soul. Alice is what made this game for me. her story is touching and you cant help but root for her, ''i hope the sun's shining, and the snow's all melted where you are.''

author: {'steamid': '76561198024601353', 'num_games_owned': 793, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1446139726}
review: Solid story focused game that can be completed in about 3 hours. Obviously the graphics aren't great but the story is worth it. Downside is that I don't see any replayability unless you want the achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034056216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1446580803}
review:
Un avventura vecchio stile con una storia ben fatta. 
Pro:
- la storia è emozionante e ben strutturata
- l'ambientazione è ben fatta
- la grafica datata lascia spazio alla fantasia
- la musica è ridotta all'osso ma adeguata
- finale multiplo (nulla di sconvolgente comunque)
Contro:
- i dialoghi sono un po' eccessivi
- la durata è scarsa
- gli enigmi sono un po' troppo semplici
In conclusione giocare a Richard & Alice è come leggere un breve racconto di fantascienza. Data la sua brevità suggerirei di acquistarlo quando è in saldo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053679878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1445894240}
review: This game is not for everyone, mature themes for sure.  I found it an intriguing story, but I wish it was just a little more open world.  The multiple endings were a nice touch but I would have liked more choice in the way the characters developed and got to those endings rather than superficial decisions.  With one exception I found the puzzles to be too simplistic, but that didn't take away from my enjoyment of the story and the characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973230221', 'num_games_owned': 14245, 'num_reviews': 849, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1446578513}
review: The game is small and short. The graphic has not much more details as it need for a nice atmosphere, the sound is simple and is good. The story is short, with many details you can read, cruel and sad. You can reach 5 different endings. Test yourself and enjoy. I give the game 74 % and hope you like what you see/ play. For short-story lovers its a worth to give the game a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006356894', 'num_games_owned': 2670, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1446166142}
review:
Very interesting and touching story, set during an eternal winter apocalypse.
Quite short (about 2.5-3 hr) point&click game, story and dialogues heavy.
There are multiple endings.
Reccomendend

author: {'steamid': '76561198168924363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1445648353}
review:
Richard & Alice is a fantastic game. It is mostly dialogue and story-driven, similar to games like To the Moon in that respect. It takes around three hours to get one of the endings.

+ Decent dialogue, although it can be awkward in places.
+ Interesting setting.
+ Storytelling is executed well.

- I felt like some characters were more developed than others.
- Slow movement speeds.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999518753', 'num_games_owned': 1800, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1474632218}
review:
This is a very simple point and click game, with a few choices that impact the ending (5 possible outcomes in total). This game is, in my opinion, below average in all regards. I'll start by the technical aspects, then go to gameplay/design choices, and finally I'll discuss the plot (I'll put it under spoilers, know that I will discuss all the twists, so don't read it if for some reason walking blind into a story is important for you).

Richard & Alice uses the Adventure Games Studio engine, a freeware development tool specific for point and click games, although it has been used for other genres from time to time. The game is functionally fine, the sounds are sparse but okay, and the music fits the theme, even if it's not memorable. The game is also very short, even if you wander around like I did, you should take about 2 hours to complete it. Not much else to say, the game doesn't stray away from the classic point and click formula, so everything works as expected, although I have seen more impressive uses of the engine.

The gameplay, despite its semplicity, manages to be disappointing thanks to the incredibly slow movement speed, paired with a couple of large, empty screens, making exploration (or back-tracking) a painful experience. Most puzzles are very easy, although I would argue one in particular is asinine in the round about way you have to go through in order to solve it. Also disappointing is just how little gameplay there is, even for a point and click. The way the ending you get is determined is probably the only clever-ish thing about it, although the results are obfuscated by how indirect some of the cause-effect links are. There is a certain amount of forced back-tracking, which is not only slow, as mentioned before, but takes you through supremely bland screens. The art is subpar, It's even less interesting than standard RPGmaker tiles, and calling it functional is probably the only praise you can bestow upon it.

The plot is not really great. If you can't tell the first plot twist in the first 5 minutes, you probably aren't very observant, or are completely unable to detect obvious storytelling devices. The second twist is slightly harder to predict, but still qualifies as a no brainer, and these are really the only surprises in the game, the rest is played out in a completely straight manner. The world building is incredibly stupid, there is no rhyme nor reason for how society seems to be organized (what little you can see or hear of it), several events are left without explanations, the dialogues are just painful (I can't tell if the kid is supposed to have some learning disabilities, or if they just poorly imitated a 5 year old, and at least a few of the rare "existential" dialogues are bland and trite, something you have likely heard before). Point and click games live and die by their story and characters, and this game doesn't provide witty, interesting, smart or likeable characters, and has to rely on the emotional crutch of family bonds for the most part just to be relatable.

Now, for the spoilers:

[spoiler]The kid is dead. It's painfully obvious, and the fact that is portrayed as a reveal it's a joke. The kid at least isn't as bad as children in other games, but only barely so. It's a cheap narrative tool that doubles as a way to manipulate you into feeling sorry for the characters. Whenever it's convenient, he'll do stupid stuff and be oblivious to his surroundings, so that you can have the story move forward, but he'll also be mature when required (and get sick to the point of no return, too). Thankfully, the game is short, so they can't drag this for too long, but it's still obvious and disappointing. You'll find several notes to read through the game, and not reading them all can affect the ending (very, VERY hard to miss them, unless you do so deliberately to get the other endings, which means you must have read a guide to know about it). The writing is a mixed bag in terms of quality here, some give you some interesting hints about what's going on, some are meant to paint the bleakness of this world, but it often isn't well put together, lacks depth or emotion, is generally unnecessary. Richard doesn't get much screen time, so you have to rely on the notes and the final parts of the game, to really flesh him out a bit. He is still a clichè, but at least he didn't mercy kill his own blood like Alice did, so at least he isn't THAT cliched. Alice is a joke, her lines are often baffling and awkward beyond the authors' intentions, (see the exchanges with Richard, or even the dialogue with the mysterious stranger in the church, supposedly the moral turning point that leads her to the decision to kill her son). The world building is disappointing, all is referred to in vague terms, but still that's what drives the characters to do what they do, something more substantial would be greatly appreciated. The game is short, so really there isn't anything worthwhile to mention beyond this.[/spoiler]

In conclusion, despite me being very negative in the review, the truth is that it's "just" a subpar game. Do not buy it, (there are much better games that tackle serious themes, while doing a much better job) unless you are really into point and click and you completely ran out of other games to play in the genre, and even then do not buy at full price, you can find better games for free, so spend your money wisely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047640878', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1443476102}
review:
To be honest, I didn't really grasp the entire meaning of this story. Regardless, the puzzles in this point and click was pretty straighforward. The only times I would say I got stuck was because I didn't play the game for some time and forgot what to do.

Getting the endings (achievments) are sort of a pain, since you can't advance dialogue (no skip function) and have to go through the story at least two times. [spoiler]Use of saves at critical moments before doing certain actions helps[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198009241651', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1444250767}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994233547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1421040921}
review:
Richard & Alice is one of those games that you're either going to really like or really, really hate, similar to Dear Esther, Gone Home, Always Sometimes Monsters, or To The Moon. It's meant to provoke an emotional response. It does this well; perhaps not as well as some of the other titles mentioned above - particularly Dear Esther, which I assume was made so you could post really depressing things to Facebook without having to personally write them (I kid, I love that game).

It's a retro-style game; the best way to describe it would be similar to RPG-Maker games. I'm not sure what engine the game uses in that regard. I think Adventure Game Maker or something like that. But anyway - the review. I'm rambling.

So Richard & Alice takes place after a post-apocalyptic event that transforms the world into [strike]northern Canada[/strike] a desolate, snow-covered wasteland. The two protagonists - Richard and, uh, you know, Alice - are trapped in an underground automated prison facility and apparently left to their own devices. Like you do when you've been captured after the end of the world due to [strike]global warming[/strike] some unknown ecological disaster, Richard and Alice begin to tell each other stories about what they did prior to their incarceration.

The gameplay itself centers around Alice's story with her little boy. Richard & Alice stays true to the adventure game roots from which it draws, relying on the point-and-click mechanic and item collection system. Think King's Quest or the Monkey Island franchise. Players who are used to the compulsive adventure game method of I WILL USE EVERY ITEM WITH THIS THING OMGBBQLOL will find that many items in the game have other uses aside from their intended ones. Many being a prejorative term, considering there are about ten or fifteen total.

Where Richard & Alice (Or R+A, like what the kids on the street say) really shines is in its ability to tell a story. Perhaps to its credit, it does not have the heavy-handed (and rather bizarre) example of [strike]creepy obsession[/strike] love that Always Sometimes Monsters displays; to its detriment - maybe, it's hard to say - it doesn't have the same emotional punch that To The Moon has.

Altogether, Richard and Alice is a short story about pain, loss, the love of a mother and child, and attempting to reconcile what all of it means. Get it if you want to feel something. It takes a couple hours and it tells something that's rather original and you likely won't be disappointed. If you are, you can blame me I suppose. I'm not entirely sure what good it would do, but that's okay, I guess.

8.5/10 - would play and have minor existential crisis after completion again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040493191', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1441583560}
review:
After having played through the game once, I recommend it in that I can imagine many people really enjoying a game like this. For my part however, the experience was mixed. 

The storytelling is fantastic, the story is interesting and if you do give it a fair shot you will get invested in it. The game didn't take too long to finish, and the graphics are good enough to convey what the game wants to convey.

On the other hand, having just finished the game once, I cannot bring myself to play through it another time. The walking you need to do with Alice is too long, too frustrating, too bland. Many of the puzzles are simple, yet others had me attempting random combinations and visiting random locations in the hope that I could find the solution. I do realise however that puzzle games are not what I excel the most at, so others might find the puzzles engaging if only a little easy at times.

I would recommend this game for its strong storytelling. It is good value for money, but unfortunately in my opinion the parts in between the storytelling are a little bit too "hit and miss" to make me want to delve into the game a second time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127939301', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1438629769}
review: Small short game, is cheap,is sad,is fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108266757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1439754869}
review: I wish there was an inbetween choice for this other than yes or no options in recommending. Meaning, I wouldn't say I "liked it" liked it, but it wasn't the worse point and click I have played... so I don't feel bad about purchasing it. It had an interesting enough story between the two characters and it has an alternative ending... though I felt the alternative ending was meh and anticlimatic. I wouldn't necessarily recommend Richard & Alice, but I wouldn't be so against somebody buying  it either. Support your indies!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041220538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1439740566}
review: I loved this game! The story sucked me right in! You honestly don't have to put much thought into the game, everything is pretty straight forward but the story was so amazing that i didn't even mind!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969331425', 'num_games_owned': 1305, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1439421355}
review:
I get that this game was trying to give you the feels and the climax of the story was SLIGHTLY unexpected (gotta give them respect there) but overall it was a really boring experience. More than half of the game is just a set up to prove that Alice loves her son. I got that in the first flashback... no need to harp on it for pretty much the entire game. It also felt really forced... I really didn't care if her son died or not. His dialogue and interactions with Alice were honestly my least favorite parts of the game.

The game itself is far longer than it needs to be. It is artificially extended by your character's slow walking speed and placing plot items on opposite corners of maps. That'd be fine if something happened in between but jesus christ I don't know how anybody plays the game multiple times to get all of the endings. It only takes a couple of hours to finish but those are some freaking boring hours.

I get what the developers were trying to do. I've just seen it done better. Frequently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151402613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1438926114}
review:
The game is over in two hours, the replay value is zero except to see alternate endings, and the gameplay itself is irritating in the snow area.

Try "To The Moon" instead.  If you haven't heard of it, google it, that game's amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071588314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1977, 'last_played': 1604763236}
review: Played this years later and its still as enjoyable as the first time. This is absolutely the best out of its kind, they don't make stories like this anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158812363', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1434579865}
review: A deep history about how low humans can go in order to survive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974991309', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1438634393}
review:
Richard & Alice is a small indie adventure which reminds me of 'To the Moon' at times, and that's a compliment. The story is interesting and rather depressing with a cool twist at the end. Also, it's emotional and adorable at times, especially with little Barney. Speaking of which, the game could've   be called Alice & Barney better, because Barney is way more interesting, and has a much bigger part than Richard.

There is no voice-acting but the backstory of the characters is well written and it's not hard to sympathize with the main characters. The game even has it's morbid moments and it lets you truly feel the world is totally f'd up.

But there's a major BUT, because sometimes I wonder if the developers weren't better of making a movie instead of a game. Really, sometimes you're listening to conversations for at least ten minutes without any form of interactivity. Then , if you're lucky, you may snoop around for a couple of minutes followed by a new, long conversation. The real adventure-sequences are not that special in any way and that's a bit of a letdown. 

However, for a couple of bucks it's worth the try. When the credits show up, you'll realize you've played a pretty neat game with a touchy story.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198183161773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1441017617}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996615830', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1412030295}
review:
Very nice story based adventure game. 10/10 worth the money.

The multiple endings are really good and different and shocking. All in all you can beat everything in 2 hours it is quick but it is a nice way to spend 10 bux if you're bored.

I highly highly recommend this game and games like it by the same publisher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077643114', 'num_games_owned': 2952, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1436838409}
review: Recomendadíssimo! História muito boa.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977105828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1435869937}
review:
What is Richard & Alice?

Genre: Point & click adventure, RPG Maker style
Setting: USA in alternate present, half the world covered in snow
Difficulty: 2/10 --> easy
Length: 2-3 hours on first playthrough, approx. 1 hour per single rerun
Mode: singleplayer campaign only


The positive aspects:

- well-written storyline with a serious tone and five different endings. That also means high replayability
- decent graphics in the typical style of RPG Maker games
- strong and credible atmosphere in a disaster-struck United States


The negative aspects:

- rather short (2-3 hours to complete), only a few places to visit
- no challenging riddles
- lacking animations, sounds and voice acting. That is a pity, because as mentioned above, the game creates a tensioning atmosphere. Could have been even better if the developers put some extra work into that issues



Result:

Regarding the pros and cons, this should be a 50-50, right? 

But it isn't: If you like games with appealing story lines and elaborated topics, this one is for you. Also, it has that retro charme, plus it's point & click. And after point and clicking through the story, you'll only see one out of a total of five different endings (depending on certain decisions made while playing). 

Definitely worth a recommmendation!

author: {'steamid': '76561198061151151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1435504245}
review:
"Richard & Alice" besticht durch seine Inszenierung. Die Dialoge, Atmosphäre, Musik, Rhythmus, Schnitte und Bildkomposition des Spiels erinnern eher an einen Kinofilm als an ein Spiel. Längere Pausen zwischen den Dialogen oder in Sequenzen nehmen dem Spieler das Tempo aus der Hand - einfach schnell durchspielen geht nicht, es wäre auch schade. Um die verschiedenen Twists in der Story vollständig zu verstehen, lohnt sich ein zweites und drittes Mal durchspielen, auch wegen der unterschiedlichen Enden.

Alles in allem ein sehr ruhiges Spiel, bei dem viel gelesen werden muss, und das in englischer Sprache (die aber in der Regel nicht schwer zu verstehen ist, obwohl oft Umgangssprache verwendet wird und auch bewusst Fehler eingebaut wurden). Sicher kein Spiel für jeden, aber wer sich darauf einlässt, kann ein wunderschönes, emotianal aufwühlendes, kleines Abenteuer erleben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026827616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1434397867}
review: A bleak story that is well paced.  Despite being heavy on the dialogue, a grim tale is woven cleverly into the sequences.  Definitely keen to see Owl Cave's next offerings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015010443', 'num_games_owned': 3180, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1434293369}
review:
Das Spiel "Richard & Alice" erzählt eine spannende und ernsthafte Geschichte über Menschlichkeit und Schicksal. Es ist ein Dialogspiel mit ein wenig Point&Click. Über die Geschichte des Spiels möchte ich nichts verraten, da sie kurz und knapp ist. Die Entscheidungen, die wir im Spiel treffen, führen zu anderen Spielverlauf und Ende.

Wer gerne Bücher auf Englisch liest, wird dieses Spiel auf jeden Fall mögen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996037034', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1434075117}
review:
It's not bad exactly, I just wouldn't really recommend it. Seeing as how games like these have very little in the way of gameplay, the game has to carry itself on story, and this one really didn't. 

The setting is kind of interesting, the story is emotional, but there's just too much that doesn't make sense. It's hard to explain why the story isn't great without using spoilers, but there are a bunch of events that just seem shoehorned in to make the story flow and just don't make any sense in the logic of the world if you stop and think about it. The major twist for one of the charaters was baltantly obvious just from the introduction. The endings seem almost completely arbitrary based on some random actions that seem unimportant.

If you really like point and click adventure games, and the setting and bleak story seem like your thing, go for it. If you're on the fence about it, I'd skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090029990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1739, 'last_played': 1611828516}
review:
Super tolles Spiel. Ich fand die Geschichte mitreißend und spannend. Ich mag das Gameplay, auch wenn es simpel ist. Es hat nich die "Extremst tolle" Grafik wie moderne Spiele, jedoch ist es passend zum Spiel. 
Es ist auf jedenfall Wert gespielt zu werden, auch für den Preis. Ob man es mag oder nicht, kann später selbst entschieden werden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005307082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1432637304}
review: The weather of world changed to cold. Snows falling down in everyday and people are going to apocalyptic end of the world. There's two people in the jail. and they have own secret story ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198126303619', 'num_games_owned': 1683, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1432107566}

author: {'steamid': '76561198067514663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1431873432}
review: The graphics aren't the greatest but story is very enjoyable and quite touching. It's a pretty sad game though so if you are in for bleak world and narrative driven game this is great. The unpleasant graphics don't really bother that much once you get sucked in by the story. Would recommend for anyone who enjoys post-apocalyptic stories and doesn't mind it's only a point and click game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046113874', 'num_games_owned': 1473, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1430540625}
review:
Dark, brilliant, and horribly beautiful.

A very basic point-and-click adventure, with generally self-evident puzzles and multiple endings. But, as with most such games (when they're any good), the real meat is in the story, themes, and overall atmosphere, and Richard & Alice excells at all three.

I didn't cry, but I came very close (and if I'd gotten a different ending I definitely might've).

author: {'steamid': '76561197996979035', 'num_games_owned': 942, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1430287556}
review: Minimal and simple point-and-click gameplay but with an emotional story. Great if you have time for the slow-burn; I didn't. I played about half an hour and read a synopsis. That's really only something I recommend if you bought the game and played through a bit of it to get a feel for the characters. Without that, the synopsis would make you feel nothing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028181030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1430270123}
review: This is more of a visual novel than a game, but there are a few things you have to figure out in order to move on. It's depressing and interesting, and I find it worthwhile for the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036649624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1429501932}
review:
A surprisingly good story that takes you a bit by surprise as it unfolds.

When you first start playing, the graphics might make you think that you have purchased a weak, amature effort at making an adventure game.

But as the game progresses, you begin to realize that everything that makes the genre great is present, and in excess.  This actually caught me off guard.  For whatever reason, I wasn't expecting much from this title going in.  Now my only regret is not having backed its development in 2012!

author: {'steamid': '76561198144974149', 'num_games_owned': 3847, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1633654508}
review:
==Cautious Recommendation; Originally written as Not Recommended==


Point of this game is to convey a significant/provocative/deep/what-have-you story; basically seems a good story. 
Heh, yeah, yeah it does.

Fault of this game is that the gameplay interferes with the point; some of the slowest walking ever - lots of backtracking / painful trial-and-error to figure out (("))puzzles((")) step by step. 
The story, having to fit with that game(play) is drawn out and tries to make characterization and interactions amongst characters be the core of that story. Thus far, the majority is banter between a loving but stressed mother and an ignorant but lovable (if not a tad annoying) child. 
Heh, yeah... yeah it is.

I understand and am not cold-hearted to the point of being put-off by that sort of exchange - not at all, I can dig it actually; a human "Shelter," (badger game) so to speak - but when I have to spend two minutes to get from one screen to the next *times* 3 (because backtracking), to be rewarded with more of the same ("No baby, blabla [I'm being pushed to the brink, not necessarily because of you, but you sure aren't helping. *trying to keep my patience and figure this out*].")...


Yet again, another game that seems would've been better off as a written story (disregarding the fact that gamers must have been the target audience, since the devs are/were apparently professional game journalists); as a video game, it is (sub-)par. Thusly,  I have to vote against it (though I don't want to). Perhaps when (-IF-) I beat it (because it's trying MY patience, too), I might find it worth the grind, as it were. For now, I must say it's too much a chore. 
Heh, yeah, yeah it is.

...That might be twisted to be a triumph, as the bleakness of the in-game world is being thrust upon the player. So. Mindfack(?) I've no interest in such... deep/pervasive storytelling if I have to push myself as hard as those who are in the story do themselves, so that I might know the story, 'specially when it hasn't even got to the gripping part yet... dig? Me neither. 


TL;DR *Meh* to *Feh* - Gameplay gets in the way of the game - Wish I could twist this into a positive. Heh, yeah, yeah I do.


EDIT: Walkthrough from Steam Guides: 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=375308346
There's no shame in following this, since the game can be such a slog (a lot of the puzzle solutions actually make sense, but the steps to achieve them aren't as apparent). Again, the point of the game is the story anyway, so cheat to get to the actual game (that is, the story). 
Should I find the story worth it - after having found that guide - I might change the Negative to Positive. Will see. 
Heh, yeah... yeah we will.

EDIT 2: When I wrote this, I was on the next to last level. Gripping part just happened... 
heh, yeah... yeah it did. 
Keep having to quit the game to look at that Guide, [strike]since there's no Steam Overlay while in-game, presumably because of the engine (but that's a whole other (angry) ramble).[/strike]

EDIT 3: There are screenshots posted of the game, so the Steam Overlay apparently does work, for some. I have a laptop hooked to a TV with a HDMI cord; I had to edit the game's files 
http://steamcommunity.com/app/279260/discussions/0/540743757019254496/#p2
to get the screen stretched to fit the TV well enough (and some of the sides were still cut off) - couldn't even see Achievement notifications, but quitting the game proved they did unlock correct. 
Beat the game; five different endings. The one I got made me sad, but I feel like it's (one of the better/)the best ending. 
Once more: Good story, grating game(play). 
SIGH
I ended up liking the story, which is the core of the game. I, then, feel like I must change my Not Recommended to Recommended. All of my criticisms still stand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086276748', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1429371367}
review:
This is a very short and unique game. It is a game containing lots of dialogue and point-and-click action.
I really enjoyed this game because it offers a sort of apocalyptic perspective through a mother's eyes and the struggles that had to be endured in order to survive in a frozen, chaotic world. The story is very emotional and will touch your heart and soul.
The graphics of this game remind me of "old school" games and give the game itself a vintage feel to it. 
The only thing that I would change about this game is to couple the dialogue with voice-over in order to give the story more emphasis and emotion. This will certainly keep a player's attention. 
Overall, I think this game is worth buying and playing for the dialogue and story alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984583928', 'num_games_owned': 2616, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1428648708}
review:
Richard & Alice is essentially a playable novel with some minor puzzle elements. I finished it in an afternoon. The story is very adult themed with some adult language. It's a deep and engrossing story that keeps you hooked all the way to the end.

The story takes place in a world where cataclysmic cold weather has forced people to fight for food and shelter in a battle-torn world. A man, Richard, is in an underground prison cell when a new prisoner, Alice, is suddenly brought into the cell across from his. These two very different people now have all the time in the world to talk and tell each other their stories.

The game takes place mostly in flashbacks, as you relive the events that brought them to their current situations. It's a very well told story, and the puzzle elements aren't too disruptive of the story-telling process. The characters move rather slowly, which makes quite a difference, when you have to move across screens, in order to solve the puzzles. Other than that, it's a great story. Definitely worth a playthrough, if you're into that sort of thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980389987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1428201235}
review:
Great story-driven game about survival but it takes around 15-20 minutes to really get going.  If you make it past this you'll  see the characters start to develop, and then it gets really good.  

This is a point-and-click game with nice item puzzles thrown in for immersion, so don't expect mind-blowing gameplay.  The story and writing are what you're here for.  I was constantly impressed by how natural the dialogue felt.  My only complaint is the walking speed is slow, and this got on my nerves on two occasions when I was trying to figure out how to progress, but it's forgiveable. 

The game takes around 4 hours to complete and I think it's the perfect length.  It never dragged and I couldn't put it down.  I was surprised to get choked up a few times, but the characters are so well written it's hard not to get attached.  There are multiple endings, but for me it ended on a perfect note.  Bravo, Owl Cave.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004986275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1413746858}
review:
The major pro of this game is the story. The major con of this game is how freaking long it takes to walk through the barren environments. Maybe it's supposed to add to the bleakness of the characters' situations, but all it did was make me bored.

I recommend this to anyone who can overlook clunky gameplay for compelling story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075650703', 'num_games_owned': 1214, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1561551864}
review:
Lovely game.

The story is quite original, though it really is grim and depressing. The music and sound effects add a lot to the ambiance. The pixel graphics are charming, the characters do feel real.

My only complaint would be the slow pace at which the characters walk and the glitched font in the main menu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147428931', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1428281243}
review:
Initial Impression- Could be interesting... after you spend a while doing a workaround just to get it working full screen!

I will update this review once I can make a better assessment. My initial impression is that it was a sloppy decision to make the user have to do a workaround just to get it working on full screen. The default mode is a windowed mode about 1/4 of my screen size.  In order to get it on full screen or a decent resolution, you need to locate the install files and open "winsetup.exe". This is the options. It will give you an error, telling you that it cannot find the required file. After this, you must make a copy of the game file "richardandalice.exe", then rename it to "richardandalice_steam_final.exe". Apparently, the game makers forgot to include this final steam exe in the installation files. Anyways... Once you do this, then you must reopen "winsetup.exe". This will allow you to disable windowed mode, which then gives you a full screen mode. However, full screen really just means the black border will then extend across the whole screen, and the game itself will remain the same windowed size. Apparently, if you want a decently visible full screen mode, you must need to do the advanced settings. For me, I was able to get a regular full screen mode by disabling the "Enable Side Borders" button. Hopefully, this will work for you. 

After this, I only played the game for a short bit. Pretty early one, the main characters discuss the idea of the morality/immorality of murder. It seems that the game will delve into this issue. According to the screenshots, it would not surprise me if this game questions not only moral issues, but also religious ones... though I cannot say for sure. If so, I'm not a fan.

So far, I've been disappointed by the sloppiness of the makers of this game in the options. Seriously, if you spent adequate time making a good game, I would hope you would do the same in the options needed to make it playable. I will update this review later. Hopefully, I am surprised.

Another Note- Since there is no ESRB rating, I'll make the following comment- This game contains strong profanity within the first 10-15 minutes, and likley throughout the rest of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121108435', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1427499375}
review:
PROS
+ classic RPG maker style (pixel graphics, multiple endings)
+ dramatic & gritty plot

CONS

- tedious to get every ending 
- story development focused mainly on one character

author: {'steamid': '76561197982814813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1427285334}
review: Très bonne expérience qui vaut pour son scénario. L'interaction du joueur est toutefois limitée pour un habitué du point & click, en termes de jeu pur et de dialogue. Les fins alternatives sont débloquées par quelques prises de décision, parfois très anodines. On pense tout le long à The Road de Cormac McCarthy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042130595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1411459673}
review:
I wanted to like this game. I'm a fan of adventure games, so this seemed like an easy choice. I was wrong.

The game has a retro 16-bit look to it. There's nothing wrong with that. However, this isn't Final Fantasy VI and this isn't 1996. The characters look clunky and move similarly. The backgrounds and similar to those found on low-budget NES titles. The game just doesn't look very good, even considering the asthetic used.

Most of the time, you read dialoge boxes. Everyone once in a while you will get to take an action. This will generally be as simple as walking to a button and pressing it. At which point, there will be 30 dialog boxes of text before you can do anything.

This is one of those indie/art games that is way more focused on the story than the gameplay. If you play adventure games for the story, you may enjoy Richard & Alice. On the other hand, if you play adventure games to explore and interact with the environment, you are out of luck. Personally, I like a good story. In games, however, I prefer story to be a backdrop to the actual gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154757644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1426124793}
review:
What a great little title!

When I first started playing this, I was not too impressed. I thought it looked really simple and there was no immediate back story to draw me in.

However, once I got past the first 10 minutes I gradually became more and more intrigued and really wanted to know what would happen next. The story really draws you in and getting to know the characters and their pasts over the course of the game is fascinating.

The graphics are actually really clever and suit the title well. The puzzles are mostly quite easy and there aren't that many, though I was stumped for a short while on one puzzle in the church. A hint or walkthrough is definitely not needed to enjoy this game to its completion. There is a lot of dialoge to read though, but it is certaimly worth reading every line as it all adds to a great atmosphere.

I guess there are multiple endings as there are dialogue options that look like they can change the outcome during the game.

I spent about 4 hours on it and very much enjoyed the experience. Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048289797', 'num_games_owned': 1462, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1425984684}

author: {'steamid': '76561198079501054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1425652056}
review:
This game is kind of different so I'll review it differently:

- This game is likely to make you cry
- This game is mostly story-driven and doesn't have a lot of gameplay
- This game has a clever and sometimes hard to understand plot
- This game is very short but intense
- Who the hell drew the trees?!

- This game tore my heart to pieces and I don't know if I want to recommend it or not. 

I will for the time being. I think it's at least worth at try whether you end up liking it or not.

-- One month later and with some perspective I have decided not to recommend this game, since it left such a bad taste in my mouth. It's just too depressing. And not in a "oh the plot was sad but also good", but just plain depressing. You'll have to decide for yourself if it's worth it... for me it was really not. --

author: {'steamid': '76561198086061585', 'num_games_owned': 2346, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1424671825}
review: Stunning and depressed story. I feel like I watch movie named "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas". Sadness along with beauty, what a perfect game like "To The Moon".

author: {'steamid': '76561197995453848', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1424663792}
review:
If you can play this game to the end, you'll notice the credits claim there were more than 10 people involved in making this thing.

This is significant, because this game doesn't do anything well.  The graphics, story, puzzles, characters,.....pretty much everything in it is something that could be thrown together by a single person that doesn't make games for a living in about a week or less.
I'm not sure how anyone can charge money for this game.  There are much higher quality games in the public domain there surpass this in every category.
If you feel any nostalgia playing this game, it's only because it feels like it was made 25 years ago.

Everyone who greenlit this should be ashamed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028201718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1424727023}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005069663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1424643076}
review:
★★★★☆ - "Worth your time, give it a bash" 

PROS:
- A strong story, which is both beautiful and heartfelt.
- The tone is just right, in a desperate survialist world affected by snow.
- The relationship between Richard & Alice is authentic and realistic, you see how it grows through fear, laughter and their sharing of both hope and memories.
- Puzzles are imaginative and thought provoking with little guidence.
- There are two endings.
- Due to clever writing nothing is ever clear as you uncover the truth.

CONS:
- The graphics are not the best but are suitable for the games style,
- In more open areas gameplay is spoilt by some poor movement.
- A somewhat short story at 3 hours.
- Although this is no con for me due to its excellent writing, there is a lot of dialog so be aware.

VERDICT?
 Story rich, with puzzle based point and click elements. This game is moving and under-rated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062085681', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1425418108}
review: If you're a fan of point-and-click games and a plot thatn will draw you in, get this title! It has good drama and small bits of light humor. You won't regret the $6 you spend on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002881050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1423905051}
review:
Als Indie Entwickler (Dead Age, Grotesque Tactics, Holy Avatar) spiele ich selbst
immer wieder gerne andere Indie Produktionen.
Richard & Alice ist ein Indie Point & Click Adventure mit einem Grafikstil der so ein
bisschen in die 16bit Area (Amiga, Atari ST) geht , irgendwie so abstrakt wie der Southpark Stil nur ohne Satire. Mit dem atmosphärischen Sound hat das gut funktioniert und wenn man bedenkt wie zu früheren Zeiten Adventure Firmen wie dtp und deren Entwickler aufgrund der hohen Kosten teilweise pleite gegangen sind, dann kann man sich schon fragen, warum nicht eigentlich so? Es ist sehr preiswert, aber trotzdem sehr atmosphärisch.

Sehr Atmosphärisch sind auch die Dialoge der wenigen Charaktere. Der Plot ist sehr gut durchdacht mit einigen unterschiedlichen Enden. Man sollte sich auf Survival und einige Grausamkeiten einstellen, aber mehr in Thriller Form, es geht nicht um Splatter oder so. Da ich Thriller über alles liebe kann ich nur sagen, das Spiel wird dem Thriller Aspekt sehr gerecht.
Ich selbst bin jetzt kein Englisch profi, komme halbwegs zurecht. Das Englisch ist hier tasächlich
gut zu verstehen und hat mich dirkt mitgerissen. Mag am Schreibstil liegen und weil später auch Kinder dabei sind, die zwangsläufig einfacher reden. xD

Ich persönlich finde Adventure Spiele super, die großen Fokus auf die Storyline legen und weniger auf Puzzles.
Die beste Spielserie in dieser Richtung waren die Nintendo DS Adventures Hotel Dusk und Last Window. Zwar kann Richard & Alice da nicht ganz mithalten auch weil es "nur" seine 6-7 Stunden Spielzeit hat, aber es hat mich schon ein bisschen daran erinnert und funktioniert ähnlich spannend. 

Für alle Adventure Freunde, die weniger wert auf Puzzles als auf eine gute Geschichte legen und
für die leicht zu verstehendes Englisch keine Hürde ist, ist dieses Indie Adventure wärmstens zu empfehlen.
Der kleine Preis rechtfertigt auch die kürzere Spielzeit, da kann man nicht meckern.

8 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198017196792', 'num_games_owned': 3699, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1423623152}
review:
Richard & Alice is quite unique. It has a good story, told in a perfect manner, very clichés characters, a very good world disaster settings, a tense atmosphere and a reeking irony. Each bit on its own isn't much or impressive but the whole thing works perfectly and will swallow you 'til the end. Several different endings, achievements, dull graphics but good sounds and music.
I really recommend the game, it's rare to find something that well thought out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053902509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1423437047}
review:
This game is a masterpiece.

The story telling is amazing, it is wonderfully paced, the ambiance and the music is great, the graphics are bland and lifeless, which is exactly what they are going for. The characters are really interesting, and overall, it was a lot of fun.

But there are some bad things to. 

The biggest bad thing is that the price to play ratio is a little off. The game is $6.00 (although I did not buy it for that, I think I got it in a humble bundle) and it only took two hours to play all the way through. Thats $3.00 an hour. I guess it is just weird because I have more than 250 hours in Just Cause 2, which only set me back $2.30. They are two completly different games, but there is still a weirds imbalance there. This would be ok if I had the desire to play the game again, but is has exactly 0 replayability, unless you want 100% of the achievments.


The only other major bad thing was that there are some story points I would love to see fleshed out, and I am very excited for a possable sequel, but I think they could have crammed more content into this game for the price.

But really, check this game out. It is sad, it made me, a 6'3" burly man cry all over my keyboard, and that is not something many games can do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028870750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1422841725}
review:
One thing for sure : this game is not for everyone.

The story is amazing but the gameplay ruined all the fun I could have have with this game : the caracters are walking so slowy ... It's painfull. Really, I suffered when I had to walk long distances in this game ... Is it a mean to make the game lasts longer ? I hope not but this is what it feels like ...
There are multiple endings but I don't think I have the courage to do 3 more playthroughs ...
The dialogs doesn't have any influence on the endings which is quite disturbing when you like to think about the best answer and make up a personality to your caracter ...

I could only recommand this game to players with a very strong patience who love puzzels and dialogs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025802559', 'num_games_owned': 2409, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1422465981}
review:
Well... I wish to devs all the best and good luck with producing next adventure games, but I'm rather disappointed by Richard & Alice. The story is decent, but framed in a game that is ugly and not entertaining. And I hated puzzles - like for example you have to built a bomb to move a statue of holy Mary - seriously? Where is logic in it? And performance - framerate was very low at snow scenes, and let's be honest, it's not Far Cry. 
And I would love it so much more if graphic style was better

So, for me it's 5/10, maybe 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198098245618', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1421661833}
review: The art is absolutely atrocious, the puzzles are 80% trivial and 20% difficult, but the storyline is fantastic and the ending sublime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1421951177}
review:
First I thought this was an RPG Maker game. It's nothing of the sort, so don't be mistaken due to the artstyle.

Owl Cave, the developing team, is clearly fond of old-school point n' click games, and this is exactly that! Honestly, there isn't much to it, [i]as a game[/i], to make it stand out. It doesn't have any interesting mechanic, or anything of the sort. It's visual and audio design is also very minimal.
Where it shines, however, is in its story! I've taken a few points to write about, but it's mostly about how they could have made it more of a game, and also overcome the downsides of old point n' clicks, with their very sluggish movement, and some frustrating puzzle design. 

This game avoids most of that, though, using the puzzles merely to get you more into the story. I will not, of course, review the story, and I'll avoid spoilers, but I'm very positive on it, overall.


[b][u]Presentation[/u][/b]
This is, by far, the weakest aspect of the game!
I've seen some people disappointed, claiming it's "MSPaint Graphics". It's not [i]that[/i] bad, for sure. But you can definitely understand that reaction. It has a very low resolution, and also simple and outdated tile sets. The structures' perspective is also a bit off... 
All in all, this is not something you'll play for sight-seeing in the least. However, it has just enough to carry the story, and giving each scene the right atmosphere, in this [b]barren and anarchic[/b] world.

Unfortunately, it's very static, which is okay, but I would have liked it not to have been in one particular aspect: the [b]character portraits[/b]. They're always the same! I realize that it was perhaps more work than it warranted, but it was a chance to add a lot of personality into the game, as I see it. Just having the portraits be in sync with their tone. Heh, it's not very important, but could have been better.

The [b]music[/b] seems to be equally as low-fi, strangely enough. It's not 8 or 16 bit or anything like that, but it somehow feels... old? It's strange to describe it. But it's mostly ambience music and sound effects, complementing the visuals to set the stage for the dialog. I found it surprisingly fitting in the game.
Everything loops well and nothing felt out of place.

There is no voice-acting.

I appreciated the [b]writting[/b] quite a lot! You can understand the tone in each character's line, and the dialogue options that they give you are always legitimate. I'll talk about this further ahead, but there are a few choices that will affect the endings, although you may not initially realize it. 


[b][u]General Structure[/u][/b]
There are 2 main characters in Richard & Alice, unsurprisingly. You're both in a prison, and all you can do is talk to each other, in separated cells. Mostly,it's about you, Richard, listening to Alice's story, about how she got there.
The game alternates between the characters. The smallest chunk of the game is in the cells, where you play as Richard, speak to Alice, and solve some very minor puzzles. It also helps you understand the world around you a bit more.
The biggest chunk, is where you play as Alice and her son, Barney, following how she was "arrested".

The prison sections are mostly there to break up the pacing, which is surprisingly good! The game never felt tiresome or to drag on as a result.


[b][u]Puzzles and Gameplay[/u][/b]
The first thing you'll notice, is how sluggish the movement is. You shouldn't be unfamiliar with it, if you're used to point n' click games... it's always their sore spot! 
This game is just the same. It's a bit awkward to move, and even to pick things up. You left click to [b]use[/b] and right click to [b]inspect[/b]. And that's basically all you need to know.
You can also advanced dialogue by clicking, skipping to the next line. There's a way to skip a scene entirely (scenes which you do not control) by holding SpaceBar -- This is never explained in the game...

You can always Save/Load at any time, which is great! There are a couple of bugs, sometimes, which can easily be fixed by simply reloading, without losing any progress.

There isn't much to the [b]puzzles[/b], honestly. It's mostly about exploring the scenes, collecting items, and then using them in the right place, or combining them. It's very standard in the genre. There isn't any pixel-hunting, and you'll generally be able to solve them rather quickly. 
During [b]most[/b] of the game, the areas are also fairly small, so every solution to a give puzzle is nearby, avoiding the slow walking that usually comes with these puzzles. 
Unfortunately, there are 2 (maybe) scenes that have 3 areas you can visit and in those, you'll [i]have to[/i] walk back and forth, very slowly, until you find the right items. That was a bit frustrating to me, as are most of point n' click games, but it was nothing unbearable. Honestly, they've avoided most of it, so that's good! It will not get in the way of the story.


Well... I think that covers it. As I can't review the story, it's hard to tell you what this game does right. The game itself is serviceable, but the way it paces the story, and gives you [i]some[/i] freedom within it is where it shines. This is definitely not something you'll play for the puzzles or mechanics. If you enjoyed To the Moon, Primordia, Home, etc. I think you'll definitely appreciate this.

The story is quite mature, and the world has gone to hell, but the story it tells is credible, and there are certainly many aspects with which the player can identify with. Some people found it depressing, which is understandable, so know what you're getting into. I don't think it's anything shocking, but it's definitely not a light-hearted and happy story. It's a lot about [b]what people would do if faced with risk of survival[/b]. It's [b]not[/b] about zombies, or nuclear war. In fact, the setting is never explained, as it's there as a mere symbol/concept. And that's all I'll say about it. 


The issue I've had with the [b]puzzles[/b] was simply the fact that you can easily miss a very specific item, for an ambiguous purpose. What I mean by that is that several other items in your inventory could provide you with the exact same utility – but of course, the game doesn't aknowledge that, and will leave you walking in circles, re-inspecting everything. That's not something I like, of course, but changing that would probably require a whole re-design of how puzzles are done in the genre, which is far outside the scope of the review. One last thing.

[b][i]How choice is handled in the different endings[/i][/b]
From what I understand, the most important choices, are the ones you make when talking to Barney. These are usually question about the state of the world that you, as a player, may not know about. It's interesting, really. It's an uninformed decision, yet, it's a valid one, since you're basically telling your son how the world is, and sometimes how people interact. And how you choose to show him, is how the ending will be presented, in a way. 
The ending is based both on deduction done with the clues you've found (depending on the notes you find, your actions in the end may change, thus changing the ending), and also based on how you chose to [i]see[/i] the world.

All in all, it will be very fitting to you, personally, and how you've played the game, it's very good!
The downside to it, is that getting several endings may be a bit laborious (since you'll have to replay big portions of the game that doesn't change much, expect for the ending), and also that the forum discussion will not be as interesting. 
Take Home, for instance. That game's discussion were based on what actually happened in the game, not just the ending. And it was great! Since in this game they're mostly about its conclusion, discussion will not be as nice. 
To be honest, I think it's good news, if such an issue is what I throw at your game, haha! 

I enjoyed it a whole lot!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048905766', 'num_games_owned': 1006, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1421733883}
review:
Richard and Alice strikes me as a hybrid mix of point & click adventure meets visual novel.  Let's start out with the high points here.  The story of Richard and Alice is absolutely compelling with a particular high note being the well written dialog between characters.  The conversational segments in the game flow naturally and realistically.  At no point did the dialog seem stilted or poorly written.  This is a particularly notable feat when one considers the amount of dialog between Alice and her 5 (and a half!) year old son Barney.  It's [i]hard[/i] to write children's dialog between parent and child in such a way that it seems natural.  Most [i]novels[/i] can't get this sort of thing right, let alone the medium of video games.  I think you almost have to be a parent yourself in order to effectively write this sort of dialog, and IMO Richard and Alice excels at it.  Creating emotional connection between the player and the in game characters is critical to this games success, and thankfully it nails this part.

The game also presents itself as an interesting piece of sci-fi.  The near future dystopia has been done to death for ages untold at this point, but Richard and Alice neatly avoids most of the typical tropes and clichés of this setting in that it never waves its world around in your face.  The setting here merely serves as a backdrop for the unfolding human drama, but for the most part leaves the concrete dystopian details as part of that backdrop.  It's a largely successful approach as it (rightly, IMO) assumes most players are sophisticated enough to be well versed in the rules of such a world by virtue of previous exposure in the form of other games, film, and books.  It effectively tells you what you need to know of the world in order to move the plot along and leaves the rest to imagination.

The gameplay is largely successful but equally does falter in some areas.  The point and click adventure elements here are fairly straight forward and rote.  There are only three relatively confined areas to explore in the game (four if you're feeling exceedingly generous).  Further, the level of interactivity in these areas is limited in such a way as to effectively move you from point A to point B in the story without a lot of tarrying about.  If you're seeking a richly vibrant, highly interactive point & click title, Richard and Alice is not necessarily going to give you that.  The world here exists as a plot device, and the interactive elements within that world are strictly limited to those that serve the plot in some way.  So yes, this is a rather tightly wound narrative without the indulgence of unnecessary distractions.  Having said that, Richard and Alice incorporates some interesting game mechanics in service to that world and to the general tone of the game.  Much has been made of the fact that character movement feels extremely sluggish, and believe me it does, it really, [i]really[/i] does.  It's my opinion though, that this was a conscious decision on the part of the developers.  The slow movement combined with the relentless sound of the snow ratchets up the tension and anxiety in the game, particularly when there are other characters in peril.  It makes the world feel claustrophobic and as if it's actively working against you.   It doesn't make it any less frustrating mind, but it is ultimately an effective decision.

The one other aspect of the game play that troubles me a bit is that of the multiple endings offered here.  There are no less than five possible endings for Richard and Alice, which would seem to indicate the possibility of a branching story line.  To be clear on this point, there are [i]absolutely no[/i] branches along the way in this story.  The ending you get is strictly based on rather arbitrary in-game choices that do not affect the narrative in progress whatsoever.  So if you want to see the multiple endings, you'll play through the [i]exact[/i] same story multiple times with the only points of differentiation being the endings themselves.  It's as if you're reading a Choose Your Own Adventure book in which the only story deviation occurs in the final two pages of the book.  Now to be clear the story [i]is[/i] excellent, and IMO it does warrant [i]at least[/i] one additional play through to pick up on the clues and hints that you may have missed the first time around.  But to play through the game [i]five times[/i] introduces a sense of drudgery and tedium, particularly when coupled with the slow character movement mentioned above.  More damningly it also reduces some of the emotional wallop present in the game with each additional playthrough.  Accordingly, if you're going for multiple playthroughs I'd recommend taking a suitable cool down period in betwixt.

I'd recommend this game to fans of visual novels (slightly more so than fans of adventure games), as well as to anyone who appreciates quality storytelling coupled with quality [i]characterization[/i] in games, especially so this latter element.

review: This game is short, but it's high caliber and gonna drag you a part of your deep sadness emotion! Litterally heart broking but also in some kind of way, educative. author: {'steamid': '76561197961371656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1421059100}
review:
This is an almost purely story-driven game similar to "To The Moon"; there is almost NO gameplay!  Despite that, I can recommend it but I believe the experience is actually improved if played with a guide (in other words, just experience the story). 

This is NOT a game in the typical sense! Know what you are getting otherwise you will not enjoy it!

PROS:
-Good dialogue
-Good characters/story

CONS:
-Art looks like MSPaint
-Walking speed is PAINFULLY slow. The puzzles are simplistic enough such that not solving one usually equates to having missed an item, combined with the slow walking speed destroys the immersion. This is why a guide is recommend as the puzzles are really simple anyway.

What you really want is a dark story, in line with other works like "The Road". You'll probably finish it in less than three hours, but there are several endings to explore. You'll have to decide which of them is "happy" for you, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159245443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1420856983}

author: {'steamid': '76561198133966847', 'num_games_owned': 452, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1420596453}
review:
If the devolper of the game is reading this, please take some advice from a fellow game designer.
This game is great, but it needs more polish.
1. Pace: This is my biggest problem with the game. It drags on like it has smashed legs. Not only is the story slow, the characters walk like they've just  learned how. It makes the game agonizingly boring. I love the game but jeez, speed it up. I feel like you went for a more drawn out story. The story has about five scenes, but the game is just so slow.
2. Plot: It never climaxes. Ever. Enough said.
3. Characters: Alice is a cool character and all, but what about Richard? His story takes place in a cell. Does he get a backstory? Is like a DLC I'm just missing out?
4. Art: It's not as good as RPG Maker. RPG Maker is only $60. You couldn't budget that?
5. Tutorial/Help: It has no help. It plops you in with no guidiance in the game. How do you know whats right?
Score: 4.5/10
Fun and interesting, but slow as all heck. It has a nice enviroment, but it needs work.
If you do want this game, buy it when it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100380821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1420172170}
